(c)  Any massage establishment operated, conducted, or maintained contrary to the provisions of this article shall be and the same is hereby declared to be unlawful and a public nuisance and the city attorney shall, in addition to or in lieu of prosecuting a criminal action hereunder, revoke the business license pursuant to the procedure set forth in section 13-277, commence an action or actions, proceeding or proceedings, for the abatement, removal and enjoinment thereof, in the manner provided by law; and shall take such other steps and shall apply to such court or courts as may have jurisdiction to grant such relief as will abate or remove such massage establishments and restrain and enjoin any person from operating, conducting, or maintaining a massage establishment contrary to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 18, 9-18-1974) 
Sec. 13-243. - Unlawful activities. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to massage any other person, or give or administer any bath or baths, or to give or administer any of the other things mentioned in this article for immoral purposes, or in a manner intended to arouse, appeal to or gratify the lust or passions or sexual desires. Any violation of this provision shall be deemed grounds for the revocation of the permit granted under this article. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 10, 9-18-1974) 
Sec. 13-244. - Employees. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of the holder of the permit and license for the massage establishment, or the employer of any person purporting to act as massage technicians, to insure that each person employed as a massage technician shall first have obtained a valid permit and license pursuant to this article. 
(b)  Any massage technician aide shall comply with the requirements of section 13-269. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 11, 9-18-1974) 
Sec. 13-245. - Inspection. 
The building inspector, fire inspector and the city health officer shall, from time to time, and at least twice each year, make an inspection of each massage establishment in the city for the purpose of determining that the provisions of this article are met. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 12, 9-18-1974) 
Sec. 13-246. - Records of treatment. 
Every person operating a massage establishment under a permit under this article shall keep a record of the date and hour of each treatment, the name and address of the patron, and the name of the technician administering such treatment. Such record shall be open to inspection by officials charged with the enforcement of this article for the purposes of law enforcement and for no other purpose. The information furnished or secured as a result of any such inspection shall be confidential. Any unauthorized disclosure or use of such information by any officer or employee of the city shall constitute a violation and such officer or employee shall be subject to the penalty provisions of this article in addition to any other penalties provided by law. Identical records shall be kept of treatments rendered off the business site, and in addition, shall describe the address where the treatment was rendered. Such records shall be maintained for a period of two years. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 13, 9-18-1974) 
Sec. 13-247. - Name of business. 
No person licensed to do business under this article shall operate under any name or conduct his business under any designation not specified in his permit. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 14, 9-18-1974) 
Sec. 13-248. - Applicability of regulations to existing businesses. 
The provisions of this article shall be applicable to all persons and businesses described herein, whether the herein described activities were established before or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives and including any person or persons whose application is presently under consideration or investigation by the city. However, those businesses operating prior to the date of adoption of this ordinance under a valid license granted by the city will have a 120-day grace period from the date of adoption within which to comply with all the conditions and requirements of this article as set forth hereinabove. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 17, 9-18-1974) 
Sec. 13-249. - Right of entry. 
The police department shall have the right to enter the building during all hours of operation. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 19, 9-18-1974) 
Sec. 13-250. - Hours of operation. 
Massage parlors shall open at 10:00 a.m., and close at 10:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 20, 9-18-1974) 
Secs. 13-251—13-265. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 13-266. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in, conduct or carry on, or to permit to be engaged in, conducted or carried on, in or upon any premises within the city the business of a massage establishment, or to render, or permit to be rendered, massage services at a location removed from a massage establishment within the city in the absence of a permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 2, 9-18-1974) 
Sec. 13-267. - Exceptions. 
The requirements of this division shall have no application and no effect upon and shall not be construed as applying to any persons designated as follows: physician, surgeon, chiropractor, osteopath or any registered or licensed vocational nurse working under the supervision of a physician, surgeon, chiropractor or osteopath duly licensed to practice their respective professions in the state; nor shall the requirements of this division apply to any treatment administered in good faith in the course of the practice of any healing art or professions by any person licensed to practice any such art or profession under the Business and Professions Code of the State of Georgia or of any other law of this state. Practical nurses or other persons without qualifications as massage technicians, or other persons not otherwise licensed by the state to practice pursuant to the laws of the state, whether employed by physicians, surgeons, chiropractors or osteopaths or not, may not give massages or massage procedures. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 3, 9-18-1974) 
Sec. 13-268. - Application—Fee. 
(a)  Any person desiring to obtain a permit to operate a massage establishment or to perform massage services shall make application to the director of finance who shall refer all such applications to the chief of police for an investigation. An application to obtain a permit to operate a massage establishment shall be accompanied by an investigation fee of $100.00. 
(b)  Each application for a permit to permit an individual to perform massage services shall be accompanied by an investigation fee of $10.00. 
(c)  Permits and fees required by this article shall be in addition to any license, permit or fee required under any other chapter of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 4, 9-18-1974) 
Sec. 13-269. - Same—Contents. 
Any applicant for a permit shall submit the following information: 
(1)  The full name and present address of the applicant. 
(2)  The two previous addresses immediately prior to the present address of the applicant. 
(3)  Written statements of at least five bona fide residents of the city that the applicant is of good moral character. 
(4)  Written proof that the applicant is over the age of 18 years. 
(5)  Applicant's height, weight, color of eyes and hair. 
(6)  Two portrait photographs at least two inches by two inches. 
(7)  Business, occupation or employment of the applicant for the three years immediately preceding the date of the application. 
(8)  The massage or similar business license history of the applicant; whether such person, in previously operating in this or another city or state under license, has had such license revoked or suspended, the reason therefor, and the business activity or occupation subsequent to such action of suspension or revocation. 
(9)  All convictions and the reasons therefor. 
(10)  A certificate from a medical doctor stating that the applicant has, within 30 days immediately prior thereto, been examined and found to be free of any contagious or communicable disease. 
(11)  Applicant must furnish a diploma or certificate of graduation from a recognized school or other institution of learning wherein the method, profession and work of massage technicians is taught. The term "recognized school" shall mean and include any school or institution of learning which has for its purpose the teaching of the theory, method, profession, or work of massage technicians, which school requires a resident course of study of not less than 200 hours to be given in not less than three calendar months before the student shall be furnished with a diploma or certificate of graduation from such school or institution of learning showing the successful completion of such course of study or learning. 
a.  Schools offering a correspondence course not requiring actual attendance of class shall not be deemed a "recognized school." The city shall have a right to confirm the fact that the applicant has actually attended classes in a recognized school for the aforementioned minimum time periods by requiring the applicant to submit to a written examination in the field of massage techniques. 
b.  In lieu of the foregoing educational requirement an applicant may submit written proof that he or she has actually been engaged in practice as a massage technician for not less than one year in the city, or five years elsewhere, preceding the date of application and shall successfully pass a written examination in massage techniques to be administered by the city. 
(12)  Such other identification and information necessary to discover the truth of the matters hereinbefore specified as required to be set forth in the application. 
(13)  Nothing contained herein shall be construed to deny to the police department of the city the right to take the fingerprints and additional photographs of the applicant, nor shall anything contained herein be construed to deny the right of the department to confirm the height and weight of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 5, 9-18-1974) 
Sec. 13-270. - Minimum requirements. 
No permit to conduct a massage establishment shall be issued unless an inspection by the city reveals that the establishment complies with each of the following minimum requirements: 
(1)  A recognizable and readable sign shall be posted at the main entrance identifying the establishment as a massage establishment; provided, that all such signs shall comply with the sign requirements of the city. 
(2)  Minimum lighting shall be provided in accordance with the city's building code, and, in addition, at least one artificial light not less than 40 watts shall be provided in each enclosed room or booth where massage services are being performed on a patron. 
(3)  Minimum ventilation shall be provided in accordance with the city's building code. 
(4)  Adequate equipment for disinfecting and sterilizing instruments used in performing the acts of massage shall be provided. 
(5)  Hot and cold running water shall be provided at all times. 
(6)  Closed cabinets shall be provided, which cabinets shall be utilized for the storage of clean linen. 
(7)  In any establishment in which massage services are rendered only to members of the same sex at any one time, such persons of the same sex may be placed in a single, separate room, or the operators of the massage establishment may elect to place such persons of the same sex in separate enclosed rooms or booths having adequate ventilation to an area outside such room or booth while massage services are being performed. 
(8)  Adequate bathing, dressing, locker, and toilet facilities shall be provided for patrons. A minimum of one tub or shower, one dressing room containing a separate locker for each patron to be served, which locker shall be capable of being locked, as well as a minimum of one toilet, and one washbasin, shall be provided by every massage establishment; provided, however, that if male and female patrons are to be served simultaneously at the establishment, separate bathing, a separate massage room, or rooms, separate dressing and separate toilet facilities shall be provided for male and for female patrons. 
(9)  All walls, ceiling, floors, pools, showers, bathtubs, steam rooms, and all other physical facilities for the establishment must be in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. Wet and dry heat rooms, steam or vapor rooms, or steam or vapor cabinets, shower compartments, and toilet rooms shall be thoroughly cleaned each day the business is in operation. Bathtubs shall be thoroughly cleaned after each use. 
(10)  Clean and sanitary towels and linens shall be provided for each patron of the establishment or each patron receiving massage services. No common use of towels or linens shall be permitted. 
(11)  A minimum of one separate washbasin shall be provided in each massage establishment for the use of employees of any such establishment, which basin shall provide soap or detergent and hot and cold running water at all times and shall be located within or as close as practicable to the area devoted to the performing of massage services. In addition, there shall be provided at each washbasin, sanitary towels placed in permanently installed dispensers. 
(12)  Proof of compliance with all applicable provisions of this Code shall be provided. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 6, 9-18-1974) 
Sec. 13-271. - Investigation; issuance. 
(a)  Any applicant for a permit pursuant to the provisions of this division shall present to the police department the application containing the aforementioned and described information. The chief of police shall have a reasonable time in which to investigate the application and the background of the applicant. Based on such investigation, the chief of police, or his representative, shall render a recommendation as to the approval or denial of the permit to the city manager. 
(b)  The building inspector, the fire department and the city health officer shall inspect the premises proposed to be devoted to the massage establishment and shall make separate recommendations to the city manager concerning compliance with this article. 
(c)  The city manager, or his designee, after receiving the aforementioned and described recommendations, shall grant a permit to the establishment if all requirements for a massage establishment described herein are met, and shall issue a permit to all persons who have applied to perform massage services unless it appears that any such person has deliberately falsified the application or unless it appears that the record of any such person reveals a conviction of a felony or a crime of moral turpitude. The city manager may recommend to the city commission that an individual business establishment shall be subject to a public hearing and city commissioners approval, when in his judgment any such business establishment has an effect upon the public health, safety, or welfare of the community. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 7, 9-18-1974) 
Sec. 13-272. - Denial; action by commission. 
Any person denied a permit by the city manager or his designee pursuant to these provisions may appeal to the city commission in writing, stating reasons why the permit should be granted. The city commission may grant or deny the permit and such decision shall be final upon the applicant. Also, the city commission may elect on its own motion to review any determination of the city manager granting or denying a permit. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 7, 9-18-1974) 
Sec. 13-273. - Nontransferable. 
All permits issued under this division are nontransferable; provided, however, a change of location of a massage establishment may be permitted pursuant to the provisions herein. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 7, 9-18-1974) 
Sec. 13-274. - Display. 
Every person to whom a permit shall have been granted under this division shall display such permit in a conspicuous place so that the same may be readily seen by persons entering the premises where the massage, bath, or treatment is given. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 8, 9-18-1974) 
Sec. 13-275. - Change of location. 
A change of location of any of the aforementioned and described premises may be approved by the chief of police and city building inspector, provided all ordinances and regulations of the city are complied with and the change of location fee of $10.00 is deposited with the city. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 9, 9-18-1974) 
Sec. 13-276. - Sale or transfer. 
(a)  Upon the sale or transfer of any interest in a massage establishment, the permit and license shall be null and void. A new application shall be made by any person desiring to own or operate the massage establishment. A fee of $10.00 shall be payable for each such application involving sale or other transfer of any interest in an existing massage establishment. The provisions of section 13-269 shall apply to any person, firm, or entity applying for a massage establishment permit for premises previously used as such establishment. 
(b)  Any sale or transfer of any interest in an existing massage establishment or any application for an extension or expansion of the building or other place of business of the massage establishment shall require inspection and shall require compliance with section 13-270. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 16, 9-18-1974) 
Sec. 13-277. - Revocation and suspension. 
(a)  No permit or license shall be revoked until after a hearing shall have been held before the city commission to determine just cause for such revocation; provided, however, the city manager or his designee may order any permits suspended pending such hearing, and it shall be unlawful for any person to carry on the business of a massage technician or to operate as a massage establishment, depending upon the particular type of permit which has been suspended, until the suspended permit has been reinstated by the city commission. Notice of such hearing shall be given in writing and served at least five days prior to the date of the hearing thereon. The notice shall state the ground of the complaint against the holder of such permit, or against the business carried on by the permittee at the massage establishment, and shall state the time and place where such hearing will be had. 
(b)  Such notice shall be served upon the permit holder by delivering the same to such person or by leaving such notice at the place of business or residence of the permit holder in the custody of a person of suitable age and discretion. If the permit holder cannot be found, and the service of such notice cannot be made in the manner herein provided, a copy of such notice shall be mailed, postage fully prepaid, addressed to the permit holder at his place of business or residence at least five days prior to the date of such hearing. 
(Ord. No. 674, art. 15, 9-18-1974) 
Secs. 13-278—13-300. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PARKING LOTS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Stopping, standing and parking, § 14-61 et seq. 

Sec. 13-301. - Compliance required. 
All persons engaged in the city in the business carried on for the accommodation of the public in providing parking and specialized service facilities for automobiles, trucks and other self-propelled vehicles for short periods of time in an open-air or roofed location on private property, for which service or facilities a charge is made, shall comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1953, § 25.1) 
Sec. 13-302. - License fee. 
Each owner or operator of parking lots regulated by this article shall pay to the city the license fee now or hereafter provided for in article II of this chapter. 
(Code 1953, § 25.2) 
Sec. 13-303. - Schedule of charges and fees to be posted. 
There shall be posted in a conspicuous place on each parking lot a schedule of charges and fees for the facilities or services provided. Such schedule shall be lettered and posted in such manner as to be legible to patrons of such business. 
(Code 1953, § 25.3) 
Sec. 13-304. - Solicitation of patrons; solicitation stands and areas. 
Solicitation of patrons by the owners, operators, agents and employees of such parking lots is hereby prohibited on the streets, lanes, alleys, sidewalks, parks and other public property of the city, except in such areas or stands as may be designated by the police department of the city. In any one such designated solicitation area or stand, no single parking lot business shall have at any one time more than two employees, agents and solicitors. Such agents, employees, owners, operators and solicitors are prohibited from engaging in loud or boisterous talk or argument while on or about such solicitation areas or stands. The police department shall not create a solicitation stand in front of any place of business where the abutting property owners object to the same or where such stand would tend to create a traffic hazard. 
(Code 1953, § 25.4) 
Sec. 13-305. - City-owned parking lots. 
(a)  The city manager is granted the power, authority, right, responsibility and duty to prescribe rules and regulations relating to the parking of vehicles on property within the city owned, leased or held by the city or other governmental agency or authority when requested in writing so to do by the commissioners or the proper and legal person or officer or official of a governmental agency or authority. Upon such request being made, and approved by the city commission, the city manager, after prescribing such rules and regulations for the parking of vehicles on such governmental owned property shall post on said property designated as a parking area a clearly visible sign upon which shall be written the rules and regulations and penalties under which vehicles may be parked, including but not limited to, hours of parking, length of time that vehicles may be parked, speed limits within said parking area, removal of vehicles from parking lot when parked over time allowed, stripping of parking areas, designation of stop signs, reservation of areas for employees and other persons, stripping and designation of walkways, and any other regulation which shall promote the safety and efficiency of the parking of such vehicles. 
(b)  The city manager shall also have the power and authority to place and install parking meters in such parking lot or rent spaces to parking customers and prescribe payment for such space. 
(Ord. No. 553, § 1, 1-19-1968) 
Secs. 13-306—13-325. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - PRECIOUS METAL DEALERS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to regulate and license dealers in precious metals, O.C.G.A. § 43-37-5. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 13-326. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Buyer of precious metals or gem stones means any person, whether as owner, agent or employee and whether a resident of the city or not, who engages in the business of purchasing precious metals or gem stones or articles containing any precious metal or gem stone from members of the general public other than for resale to the general public in a retail jewelry or antique business conducted at the same location or as a pawnbroker. 
Gem stones means diamonds, rubies, emeralds or sapphires. 
Precious metals means gold, silver or platinum or any metal containing gold, silver or platinum. 
(Ord. No. 764, § 2, 10-1-1980) 
Sec. 13-327. - Records—Required. 
Every buyer of precious metals and gem stones shall maintain a daily record in which shall be entered in legible English at the time of each transaction the following information: 
(1)  The date and time of day of the transaction. 
(2)  The name of the person conducting the transaction. 
(3)  The name, age, address and race of the seller, a description of the general appearance and estimated height and weight of the seller; and the distinctive number from the seller's driver's license or other similar identification card. 
(4)  A full identification and description of the article or articles including kind, style, material, color, design and kind and number of stones in jewelry, if any, and all identifying marks and numbers inscribed thereon. 
(5)  The price paid for each item. 
(6)  The number of the check issued for the purchase price if payment is made by check. 
(7)  The signature of the customer. 
(Ord. No. 764, § 8, 10-1-1980) 
Sec. 13-328. - Same—Entries. 
Entries in the records required by section 13-327 shall appear in chronological order in ink. No blank lines may be left between entries. No obliterations, alterations, or erasures may be made. Corrections shall be made by drawing a line of ink through the entry without destroying its legibility. 
(Ord. No. 764, § 9, 10-1-1980) 
Sec. 13-329. - Same—Filing with city; inspection. 
The complete daily record of each day's transactions shall be filed on or before the following day in the office of the city marshal and shall, prior to filing, be open to the inspection of any duly authorized law enforcement officer during the ordinary hours of business or at any reasonable time. 
(Ord. No. 764, § 10, 10-1-1980) 
Sec. 13-330. - Minimum retention period. 
Every buyer of precious metals or gem stones shall retain possession of each article or item purchased in the city for at least ten days following each purchase. It shall be unlawful for any buyer of precious metals or gem stones to alter in any manner, or to transfer possession of, any article or item purchased in the city within a period of ten days or less after purchase. In the event that any article or item so purchased shall be removed from the city limits within a period of ten days after purchase, the buyer of precious metals or gem stones shall notify the city marshal, in writing, prior to such removal, of the precise location and address to which the article or item shall be removed and shall consent to inspection of the same by the city marshal or any duly authorized law enforcement officer, at such location. 
(Ord. No. 764, § 11, 10-1-1980) 
Sec. 13-331. - Unlawful acts. 
It shall be unlawful for any buyer of precious metals or gem stones to commit any of the following acts: 
(1)  Fail to make an entry of any material matter in his daily record. 
(2)  Make any false entry therein. 
(3)  Falsify, obliterate or destroy such daily record or remove the same from his place of business except to file the same in the office of the city marshal. 
(4)  Refuse to allow any duly authorized law enforcement officer to inspect such daily record or any goods in his possession, during the ordinary hours of business or at any reasonable time. 
(5)  Fail to file his daily record in the office of the city marshal. 
(6)  Fail to comply with this article in any other particular. 
(Ord. No. 764, § 13, 10-1-1980) 
Secs. 13-332—13-345. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 13-346. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for a buyer of precious metals and gem stones to engage in such business within the city without first obtaining a license therefor in compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 764, § 1, 10-1-1980) 
Sec. 13-347. - Application. 
The applicants for a license pursuant to this division shall file with the city marshal a written application under oath, signed by the applicant if an individual, by all partners if a partnership, and by the president if a corporation and showing as follows: 
(1)  The name or names of the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that it will be carried on within the city; the local address or addresses of such person while engaged in such business; the permanent address or addresses of such person or persons; the capacity in which such person will act (that is, whether as proprietor, agent or otherwise); the name and address of the person for whose account the business will be carried on, if any; and if a corporation, the name of the state in which the same is incorporated. 
(2)  The place or places within the city where it is proposed to carry on the applicant's business and the length of time during which it is proposed that such business will be conducted. 
(3)  Credentials from the person for which the applicant proposes to do business, authorizing the applicant to act as representative. 
(4)  Such other reasonable information as to the identity and character of the person or persons having the management or supervision of the business and the manner of doing business as the city marshal may deem proper in order to fulfill the purpose of this article in the protection of the public interest. 
(Ord. No. 764, § 3, 10-1-1980) 
Sec. 13-348. - Bond. 
Before any license shall be issued pursuant to this division, the applicant shall file with the city marshal a bond binding the applicant to the city in the full sum of $10,000.00, executed by the applicant as principal and by a surety approved by the city marshal, conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with the ordinances of the city and the statutes of the state governing the conduct of such business and will pay all judgments rendered against the applicant for any violation of such ordinances or statutes and all judgments that may be recovered against the applicant by any person or persons for damages arising out of the conduct of such business. Action on the bond may be brought in the name of the city in its own behalf or for the use of any aggrieved person. 
(Ord. No. 764, § 4, 10-1-1980) 
Sec. 13-349. - Agent for service of process. 
Before any license shall be issued pursuant to this division, the applicant shall file with the city marshal an instrument appointing the secretary of the city commission as his true and lawful agent for service of process upon the applicant in any suit or legal proceeding arising out of the business transacted pursuant to the license applied for or for the performance of the conditions of the required bond or for any breach thereof. Immediately upon service of process upon the secretary of the commission as herein provided, the secretary shall send to the licensee at his last-known address, by registered mail, a copy of such process. 
(Ord. No. 764, § 5, 10-1-1980) 
Sec. 13-350. - Display; separate licenses for separate places of business. 
The license issued pursuant to this division shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business named therein. In the event that the applicant shall desire to do business in more than one place within the city, separate licenses shall be purchased and issued for each place of business, and shall be posted conspicuously in each place of business. 
(Ord. No. 764, § 6, 10-1-1980) 
Sec. 13-351. - License fees. 
Licensees under this division shall pay a license fee of $300.00 for each calendar year or portion thereof in which the licensee shall engage in business within the city. For each business location in addition to one, the licensee shall pay an additional license fee of $75.00 for each calendar year or portion of year in which the licensee conducts business at such additional location or locations. 
(Ord. No. 764, § 7, 10-1-1980) 
Sec. 13-352. - Revocation. 
(a)  The license issued pursuant to this division may be revoked by the city commission, after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license. 
(2)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in connection with any purchase transaction. 
(3)  Failure to maintain the daily record required by this article. 
(4)  Any other violation of this article. 
(5)  Conducting the business licensed under this article in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(b)  Notice of hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. The notice shall be served on the licensee by handing the same personally to the person in charge of the licensee's business, or by mailing the same, postage prepaid, to the licensee at his last-known address at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(c)  The giving of such notice shall suspend the license pending the outcome of the hearing, and business operations under the license shall cease. 
(Ord. No. 764, § 12, 10-1-1980) 
Secs. 13-353—13-430. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - RESERVED[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 919, § 1, adopted Dec. 24, 1994, repealed former art. XI of this chapter in its entirety. Former art. XI, §§ 13-431—13-436, pertained to professionals and derived from Ord. No. 774, §§ 1—5, 7, 8, adopted Oct. 21, 1981. 

Secs. 13-431—13-455. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - PUBLIC DANCE HALLS 

Sec. 13-456. - Definition. 
The term "public dance hall," as used in this article, shall include any dance hall where a dance is held to which admission may be gained by the general public, where an orchestra furnishes the music, but shall not include any dance hall wherein a dance is held to which admission is restricted to invited guests. 
(Code 1953, § 13.1) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 13-457. - License required. 
No person shall conduct any public dance hall without first obtaining the license required by article II of this chapter, and complying with all of the terms of such article. 
(Code 1953, § 13.2) 
Sec. 13-458. - Prerequisite to issuance of license. 
No license required by section 13-457 shall be issued where the dance hall is situated within the first fire district unless a petition shall be first presented to the city commission duly approved and signed by at least three-fourths of the residents living within 450 feet of the location of such hall. 
(Code 1953, § 13.3) 
Sec. 13-459. - Revocation of license. 
The city commission shall have the right to revoke the license granted to any person for the operation of a public dance hall if there has been any boisterous, riotous or disorderly conduct or if the maintenance of such public dance hall or place for dancing shall disturb the public peace. Before revoking any such license, the commission shall allow the holder of such license a hearing. Five days' notice of such hearing shall be given to the holder in writing, together with a brief statement of the grounds upon which the commission proposes to revoke such license. If at such hearing the holder fails to appear or fails to show any good and sufficient reason in the judgment of the commission why his license should not be revoked, the commission shall revoke and cancel such license. It shall thereafter be unlawful for the holder of any such license to operate such public dance hall. 
(Code 1953, § 13.4) 
Secs. 13-460—13-480. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - TELEPHONE COMPANIES 

Sec. 13-481. - Authority for tax. 
The Georgia Public Service Commission, through an order dated February 18, 1971, provides for local service revenues as a base for occupational tax as it relates to telephone companies doing business within the city. 
(Ord. No. 616, § 1, 7-7-1971) 
Sec. 13-482. - Tax levied. 
The telephone company doing business in the city is to remit to the city finance director payment equal to three percent of the local service revenues in two installments, one on or before May 1, and the other on or before September 1, in each given year. 
(Ord. No. 616, § 2, 7-7-1971) 
Sec. 13-483. - Application to franchisee. 
The franchise agreement now in effect with Southern Bell Telephone Company is in no way affected by this change in rate method or manner of the payment of this occupational tax, and any franchise fees are to be paid along with this occupational tax at the time of remittance. 
(Ord. No. 616, § 3, 7-7-1971) 
Secs. 13-484—13-505. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 947, § 1, adopted Jan. 16, 2002, change the title of art. XIV of this chapter from "transient merchants, itinerant merchants and itinerant vendors" to "transient merchants." 
State Law reference— Peddlers and itinerant trades, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 13-506. - Definition. 
(a)  For the purpose of this article, a "transient merchant," "itinerant merchant" or "itinerant vendor" is defined as any person, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, and whether a resident of the city or not, who engages in a business of selling goods, wares, merchandise or services temporarily within the city and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, shop, apartment or room in a hotel, motel or lodging house, tent, motor vehicle or railroad car, or any street, alley or other place within the city, for the exhibition for sale of such goods, wares and merchandise or performance of such services, either privately, publicly or at auction. The person so engaged shall not be relieved from complying with the provisions of this article by reason of associating temporarily with any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer, or by conducting such transient business in connection with or in the name of any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer. 
(b)  The definition set forth in this section shall not be deemed to include any person who, while occupying such temporary location, merely takes orders for the sale of goods for future delivery or exhibits samples for the purpose of securing orders only for future delivery. Such definition shall be deemed to include any person engaged in the performance of any service such as fitting, measuring, planning, designing, photographing or any other service of similar kind, notwithstanding that such service may contemplate the future delivery of tangible property. 
(Ord. No. 735½, §§ 2, 3, 6-21-1978) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 13-507. - Use of streets, parks, etc. 
(a)  No transient merchant shall conduct, in whole or part, a business upon any public sidewalk, street, alley, park, right-of-way or other public lands of the city without first obtaining the consent of the city commission after furnishing proof satisfactory to the commission that the location and conduct of such business with neither obstruct such public ways and places, nor interfere with the orderly regulation of traffic, nor interfere with the right of the general public to the use of such public ways and places; provided, however, that the market at Mary Ross Waterfront Park and such other places as the commission may from time to time designate may be used for transient merchant business subject to any terms, fees and conditions as may be provided for by the city manager or such other person or persons as the commission may place in charge of management of the facility. 
(b)  No transient merchant shall conduct a business upon any privately owned property without first providing the deputy city marshal with written authorization for such use of the property, identifying the owner thereof and signed by the owner. 
(c)  No transient merchant shall locate any business in any residential-zoned area. 
(Ord. No. 735½, § 9, 6-21-1978; Ord. No. 947, § 2, 1-16-2002) 
Sec. 13-508. - Report of sales subject to sales tax. 
It shall be the duty of each transient merchant, itinerant merchant, or itinerant vendor, after having engaged in business within the city, to report to the deputy city marshal the amount of gross sales made within the city during the period while the license was in effect and to furnish proof that all taxes due to the commissioner of revenue of the state upon such sales, including the local option sales tax, have been remitted to the commissioner of revenue as required by state law. Such report of gross sales and proof of tax payment thereon shall be filed with the deputy city marshal at the time payment is due to the commissioner of revenue. 
(Ord. No. 735½, § 12, 6-21-1978) 
Sec. 13-509. - Violations. 
Failure to comply with the licensing, application and other requirements of this article XIV shall be deemed a violation of the City Code punishable as provided for in chapter 15 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 947, § 4, 1-16-2002) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 947, § 4, adopted Jan. 16, 2002, added new provisions to this article as § 13-530 of div. 2. As such provisions pertained to art. IV as a whole, said provisions have been redesignated as § 13-509 by the editor for purposes of classification. 
Secs. 13-510—13-520. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 13-521. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for a transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor to engage in such business within the city without first obtaining a license therefor in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 735½, § 1, 6-21-1978) 
Sec. 13-522. - Application. 
Applicants for a license under this division shall file with the deputy city marshal a written application under oath, signed by the applicant if an individual, by all partners if a partnership, and by the president if a corporation, and showing as follows: 
(1)  The name of the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business during the time it is proposed that it will be carried on within the city; the local address of such person while engaged in such business; the permanent address of such person; the capacity in which such person will act (that is, whether as proprietor, agent or otherwise); the name and address of the person for whose account the business will be carried on, if any; and if a corporation, the state of the incorporation. 
(2)  The place or places within the city where it is proposed to carry on the applicant's business and the length of time during which it is proposed that such business will be conducted at each location. Where the transient business will be conducted upon privately owned property, the signed, written documentation of owner permission as required by section 13-507(b) shall be appended to the application. 
(3)  The place or places other than the permanent place of business of the applicant where the applicant conducted a transient business within the six-month period next preceding the date of application, stating the nature of each such business and giving the post office and street address of the location at which the business was conducted and identifying the local licensing entity for each. 
(4)  A statement of the nature, character, quality and quantity of the goods, produce, wares, merchandise or services to be sold or offered by the applicant within the city; whether the same are proposed to be sold from stock in possession, by sample, at auction, by direct sale, by taking orders for future delivery or any combination of the foregoing; where the goods or products to be sold are manufactured or produced and where the goods or products are located at the time of application. Where the applicant proposes to sell goods, wares and merchandise from stock in possession, there shall be appended to the application a complete and itemized list of the articles to be sold, which shall be signed by the applicant and verified under oath. 
(5)  Written documentation or credentials from the person or company for which the applicant proposes to do business, authorizing the applicant to act as a representative. 
(6)  A list of the full and correct names of all persons who will or may be employed in the transient business. 
(7)  A listing of any prior periods when the applicant has carried on a transient business with the city. 
(8)  An acknowledgement that applicant has been furnished with a copy of article XIV, chapter 13 of the City Code and will abide by all city ordinances in conducting the proposed transient business. 
(Ord. No. 735½, § 4, 6-21-1978; Ord. No. 947, § 3, 1-16-2002) 
Sec. 13-523. - Sales tax number required. 
Before any license shall be issued pursuant to this division, the applicant shall file with the deputy city marshal proof satisfactory to the deputy city marshal that the applicant or the business proposed to be conducted pursuant to the license possesses a valid state sales tax number issued by the commissioner of revenue of the state. 
(Ord. No. 735½, § 5, 6-21-1978) 
Sec. 13-524. - Bond. 
Before any license shall be issued pursuant to this division, the applicant shall file with the deputy city marshal a bond binding the applicant to the city in the full sum of $10,000.00, executed by the applicant as principal and by a surety approved by the deputy city marshal, conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with the ordinances of the city and the statutes of the state governing the conduct of such business and will pay all judgments rendered against the applicant for any violation of such ordinances or statutes and all judgments that may be recovered against the applicant by any person or persons for damages growing out of any misrepresentation, deception or breach of warranty in the conduct of such business. Action on the bond may be brought in the name of the city for the use of any aggrieved person. 
(Ord. No. 735½, § 6, 6-21-1978) 
Sec. 13-525. - Agent for service of process. 
Before any license shall be issued pursuant to this division, the applicant shall file with the deputy city marshal an instrument appointing the secretary of the city commission as his true and lawful agent for service of process upon the applicant in any suit or legal proceeding arising out of the business transacted pursuant to the license applied for or for the performance of the conditions of the aforesaid bond or for any breach thereof. Immediately upon service of process upon the secretary of the city commission, the secretary shall send to the licensee at his last-known address, by registered mail, a copy of such process. 
(Ord. No. 735½, § 7, 6-21-1978) 
Sec. 13-526. - Display; separate licenses for separate places of business. 
The license issued pursuant to this division shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business named therein. In the event that the applicant shall desire to do business in more than one place within the city, separate licenses shall be purchased and issued for each place of business, and shall be posted conspicuously in each place of business. 
(Ord. No. 735½, § 8, 6-21-1978) 
Sec. 13-527. - Activity restricted. 
No license issued pursuant to this division shall carry with it the privilege of making a house-to-house canvass of residences and offering for sale and delivery goods or services of any character if such canvass shall be otherwise regulated by the city. 
(Ord. No. 735½, § 8, 6-21-1978) 
Sec. 13-528. - Fee, occupational tax. 
(a)  Licensees under this division shall pay an initial minimum license fee at the time of issuance of the license, equal to $25.00 for each day upon which business will be conducted pursuant to the license. 
(b)  At the time of filing the report of gross sales required by section 13-508, the licensee shall pay a gross receipts license tax equivalent to the amount which the licensee would have paid pursuant to article II of this chapter if licensed under article II of this chapter less a credit for the initial minimum license fee paid at the time of issuance of the license. 
(c)  In computing the taxes to be paid pursuant to subsection (b) of this section, all gross receipts derived in the city during a calendar year shall be cumulative, it being the intent of this section to require transient or itinerant merchants and vendors to pay license fees and occupational taxes not less than those paid by businesses having permanent locations within the city. 
(d)  Failure to comply with section 13-508 or with subsections (b) and (c) of this section shall constitute ground to refuse the issuance of a subsequent license to a transient or itinerant merchant or vendor. 
(Ord. No. 735½, § 10, 6-21-1978; Ord. No. 823, § 1, 9-14-1985) 
Sec. 13-529. - Revocation. 
(a)  The licenses issued pursuant to this division may be revoked by the board of city commissioners, after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license. 
(2)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in connection with the selling of goods, wares, merchandise or services. 
(3)  Any violation of this article. 
(4)  Conducting the business licensed under this division in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(b)  Notice of hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. The notice shall be served on the licensee by handing the same personally to the person in charge of the license's business, or by mailing the same, postage prepaid, to the licensee at his last-known address at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(c)  The giving of such notice shall suspend the license pending the outcome of the hearing, and business operations under the license shall cease. 
(Ord. No. 735½, § 11, 6-21-1978) 
Sec. 13-530. - Liability for payment of taxes due. 
No license shall be issued to a transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor pursuant to this division unless the records on file in the office of the deputy city marshal show that the applicant has paid all taxes due upon any prior sales made within the city. 
(Ord. No. 735½, § 13, 6-21-1978) 
Secs. 13-531—13-555. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - WRECKERS[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference— Ambulances, § 13-71 et seq.; motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 14; taxicabs, ch. 21. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 13-556. - Title. 
This article shall be known and cited as "the wrecker ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 832, § 1, 2-19-1986) 
Sec. 13-557. - Definitions. 
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this article shall be as follows: 
Chief means the chief of the police department of the city or any officer specifically designated by him to administer and carry out the provisions of this article. 
Disabled means a motor vehicle disabled on a public way or other public place in such a manner as to obstruct vehicular or pedestrian travel or access to public or private property. 
Operator means and includes all persons owning or operating wreckers within a wrecker service in the city and all officers, agents and employees of such persons who are engaged in the business of the wrecker service. 
Wrecker means an automotive vehicle equipped and used for the purpose of towing or hauling wrecked or disabled automobiles or other vehicles. 
Wrecker service means any person regularly engaged in the business of towing or hauling wrecked or disabled motor vehicles for hire within the city whether or not such wrecker service maintains an office within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 2, 2-19-1986) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 13-558. - Administration and enforcement. 
It shall be the duty of the chief to administer and carry out the provisions of this article. All law enforcement officers of the city shall have authority to prosecute violations of this article. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 3, 2-19-1986) 
Sec. 13-559. - Penalty for violations. 
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions or sections of this article, shall be punished upon conviction in the municipal court in accordance with section 1-6. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 26, 2-19-1986) 
Sec. 13-560. - Compliance required. 
It shall be unlawful for any wrecker service or operator to tow or haul any motor vehicle which has been wrecked, abandoned or disabled on a public way or other public place within the jurisdiction of the city from the scene of the wreck, abandonment or disablement except in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 4, 2-19-1986) 
Sec. 13-561. - Removal of debris. 
The removal of broken glass and other debris from the scene of an accident shall be part of the wrecker service's obligation pursuant to this article. When two or more different wrecker services are assigned to one accident, each shall be equally responsible for cleaning the wreck area. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 9, 2-19-1986) 
Sec. 13-562. - Use of emergency light. 
A wrecker operator shall not display the amber emergency light except upon arrival at the scene where a call originated and when leaving the scene with a vehicle in tow. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 10, 2-19-1986) 
Sec. 13-563. - Obedience to traffic laws. 
Each wrecker operator shall abide by all applicable traffic regulations. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 10, 2-19-1986) 
Sec. 13-564. - Responsibility for violations. 
Each wrecker operator shall be responsible for any violation of any applicable law, rule or regulation incurred in the process of responding to a call. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 10, 2-19-1986) 
Sec. 13-565. - Storage area. 
(a)  Each wrecker service shall maintain an area for storage of towed vehicles either within or without the city, sufficient to provide storage in a manner not inconsistent with applicable zoning ordinances and other laws. If outside the city, the storage area shall be no more than three miles from the city limits by the shortest route of vehicular travel. 
(b)  The storage area shall be enclosed or fenced, shall be securely locked at all times when unattended, shall be lighted during night time, and shall be used for temporary storage only. 
(c)  Towed or hauled vehicles shall not be parked or left standing on any city right-of-way at any time or under any circumstances. 
(d)  Stored vehicles shall be subject to reclamation 24 hours a day. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 11, 2-19-1986; Ord. No. 837, § 2, 5-7-1986) 
Sec. 13-566. - Comprehensive liability insurance coverage. 
In addition to the motor vehicle liability insurance required by state law, each wrecker service shall maintain general comprehensive liability insurance on business operations providing a minimum of $25,000.00 single-limit coverage per occurrence. The chief may require each wrecker service to furnish copies of its insurance certificates showing the amounts of coverage and expiration of the policies required by this article and other laws. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 12, 2-19-1986) 
Sec. 13-567. - Identification of vehicles. 
Each wrecker shall have the name, address and telephone number of its business displayed on both sides of the vehicle. Such information shall be permanently painted onto the side of the vehicle in block letters of contrasting color not less than 2½ inches in height. Attachment to the vehicle of removable signs for this purpose is strictly prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 13, 2-19-1986) 
Sec. 13-568. - Solicitation of business prohibited. 
It shall be a violation of this article for any wrecker operator, wrecker service or other person to solicit business at the scene of a motor vehicle accident or other vehicular disablement, whether such solicitation be conducted from a wrecker vehicle, private automobile, other vehicle or on foot. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 17, 2-19-1986) 
Sec. 13-569. - Removal of vehicles restricted. 
No vehicle shall be removed from the scene of a wreck, abandonment or disablement until it is released by the investigating officers. The chief or other officers of the city police department may direct that a vehicle to be removed shall be impounded and towed or hauled to the city's impound lot, and in such event it shall be a violation of this article for any wrecker operator to remove a vehicle to any other location. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 19, 2-19-1986) 
Sec. 13-570. - Records. 
After towing or hauling a wrecked or disabled vehicle, a wrecker service shall immediately make a written record of the following information, which shall be maintained for a period of one year and which shall be made available for inspection and copying by the chief at all reasonable business hours: 
(1)  The name of the owner of the vehicle; 
(2)  The make, model and serial number of the vehicle; 
(3)  The date and time towed or hauled; 
(4)  The location of the wreck or disablement; 
(5)  The place where such vehicle was stored or other disposition of the vehicle; and 
(6)  An itemization of the charges made by the wrecker service for towing the vehicle and the charges made or accruing for storage of the same. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 20, 2-19-1986; Ord. No. 928, § 3, 11-20-1996) 
Secs. 13-571—13-585. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ROTATION LIST 

Sec. 13-586. - Use required; exceptions. 
At all times when necessary for the police department to remove any motor vehicle for any cause from any place within the jurisdiction of the city, no wrecker shall be used to tow or haul such vehicle unless that wrecker is on the city's rotation system; provided, however, that this article shall not be construed to prohibit the police department from using a wrecker owned by the city to tow or haul an abandoned vehicle or a vehicle to be impounded in connection with a criminal investigation or to prohibit the use of a wrecker not on the rotation system under circumstances where police jurisdiction is not involved. For purposes of this section, police jurisdiction shall be deemed to exist in all cases of vehicular wreck or collision, all cases in which a criminal offense is under investigation, all cases in which a vehicular disablement results in obstruction of use of or travel on a public place or way, and all cases of abandonment of a vehicle on a public place or way. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 5, 2-19-1986; Ord. No. 837, § 1, 5-7-1986) 
Sec. 13-587. - Application for placement. 
In order to be placed on the rotation system, the owner or operator of a wrecker shall file an application with the chief, supplying the following information: 
(a)  Title certificate number of the wrecker and date issued and the name, home and business address and telephone number(s) of the owner or owners of the wrecker. 
(b)  Complete home and business address and telephone numbers of the principal operator of the wrecker. 
(c)  Description of the wrecker to be registered, including the make, model, manufacturer's serial number and capacities. 
(d)  Names of the wrecker service operating the wrecker and all persons having a financial interest therein. 
(e)  Persons, including all agents and employees, authorized to operate the wrecker and class of driver's license held by each operator. 
(f)  A current three-year certified Motor Vehicle Report (MVR) from the Georgia Department of Driver Services (DDS) for each driver who will be operating a wrecker or tow truck. 
(g)  The location and telephone number of the office or garage to and from which the wrecker is operator. 
(h)  The name and address of the insurance company or companies providing motor vehicle liability coverage for the wrecker and wrecker service and general comprehensive liability coverage for business operations, the policy number of each insurance policy, and the policy limits provided by each policy. 
(i)  Proof of a minimum of six months pre-paid insurance coverage or a certificate of insurance. 
(j)  A copy of the company's current City of Brunswick business license. 
(k)  A copy of the motor vehicle registration for the wrecker. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 6, 2-19-1986; Ord. No. 1045, § 1, 9-21-2016) 
Sec. 13-588. - Inspection of vehicles. 
All wreckers shall undergo annual safety compliance inspections in compliance with the department of transportation's motor carrier compliance division. Proof of the annual safety inspections shall be submitted to the chief before approving the application for placement on the rotation system. Thereafter, the chief shall inspect each wrecker's pertinent documents annually. Each wrecker owner may provide multiple wrecker units so long as each vehicle is inspected in accordance with this article. Provided however, that a wrecker owner or company shall only be afforded one slot on the wrecker list. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 7, 2-19-1986; Ord. No. 928, § 2, 11-20-1996; Ord. No. 1045, § 1, 9-21-2016) 
Sec. 13-589. - Minimum specifications, equipment. 
The following items and equipment must be maintained on all wreckers and tow trucks: 
(a)  Each vehicle must be permanently marked on both sides of the body or cab of the vehicle, in letters and figures in sharp color contrast to the background and legible from a distance of 50 feet during daylight hours while the vehicle is stationary, with: 
(1)  The name of the motor carrier (wrecker company) city of address, and telephone number; and 
(2)  The carrier's state or federal USDOT number; 
(b)  Valid registration tag and revalidation decal; 
(c)  Valid emergency light permit issued by DPS; 
(d)  Flashing or revolving amber light with 360-degree visibility; 
(e)  Battery jumper cables; 
(f)  Fire extinguisher; 
(g)  Sweeping broom; 
(h)  Flat shovel; 
(i)  Container for debris; 
(j)  Motorcycle straps (4); and 
(k)  Tow away lamps (tail, stop and turn signal lights for vehicles being towed); and 
(l)  Stopped vehicle warning devices (e.g. three bi-directional reflective triangles). 
(Ord. No. 832, § 8, 2-19-1986; Ord. No. 1045, § 1, 9-21-2016) 
Sec. 13-590. - Preparation of call list. 
It shall be the duty of the chief or his/her designee to prepare and maintain a rotational call list of wreckers which meet the qualifications, standards, and requirements enumerated in this article. Each wrecker company shall be afforded one slot on the wrecker list. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 14, 2-19-1986; Ord. No. 1045, § 1, 9-21-2016) 
Sec. 13-591. - Use of call list—Generally. 
(a)  At all times when necessary for the police department to remove any vehicle for any cause, the police radio operator, or such other person as may be designated by the chief, shall engage the services of those on the rotational call list by calling them in alphabetical order and in rotation, provided, however, that deviation from the alphabetical order shall be permitted if: 
(1)  The next wrecker service on rotation does not have a wrecker available with sufficient capacity to handle the call, or 
(2)  The owner or person in possession of a vehicle or person in possession of a vehicle about to be removed designates a wrecker service of his preference. In the event such person designates a wrecker service of his preference, that wrecker service shall be called whether or not it is next on the rotational call list, and such designation shall not interfere with such wrecker service's position on the call list. 
(b)  If it is necessary to skip over one or more wrecker services because they do not have a wrecker with sufficient capacity to handle a particular call, the wrecker service or services skipped over shall not lose position on the rotation list, but the wrecker service which handles the call shall lose position. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 15, 2-19-1986; Ord. No. 837, § 3, 5-7-1986) 
Sec. 13-592. - Same—Unauthorized. 
All calls to wrecker services shall be made by the police radio operator, or such other person as may be designated by the chief, and in no event shall an investigating officer undertake to call directly for a wrecker service. Police officers are strictly forbidden from recommending any particular wrecker service to any person, and any police officer violating this provision shall be subject to appropriate disciplinary action. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 16, 2-19-1986) 
Sec. 13-593. - Call of wrecker to scene. 
It shall be a violation of this article for any wrecker operator to proceed to the scene of an accident or vehicular disablement unless called as provided hereinabove. Upon being so called, a wrecker operator shall not block traffic and shall maintain his vehicle in such position as not to impede emergency vehicles and normal vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 18, 2-19-1986) 
Sec. 13-594. - Fees. 
A wrecker service shall pay an annual fee of $50.00 for placement on the rotation system and an application fee of $50.00. Such fees shall be paid to the City of Brunswick Finance Department for administrative costs associated with the enforcement of this article. There shall be no gross receipts tax or other license fees for wrecker operations, but such tax may apply to other business activities of a wrecker service. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 21, 2-19-1986; Ord. No. 1045, § 1, 9-21-2016) 
Sec. 13-595. - Charges. 
(a)  The mayor and city commission shall set forth an appropriate fee schedule to be binding on the wrecker services included on the rotational list. This fee schedule may be reviewed not more than once annually. 
(b)  As approved in paragraph (a) of this section, no wrecker service shall charge more than the following fees for services provided when responding to a call received from the rotational call list: 
(1)  Attaching and towing or hauling a vehicle ..... $125.00 
(2)  Storage per day, starting at 12:01 a.m. of the next calendar date following the tow date, per day ..... $15.00 
(3)  Outdoor storage, per day ..... $10.00 
(4)  All other services performed within a reasonable time, including but not limited to, righting an overturned vehicle, removing vehicle from marsh, cleaning accident scene, etc., to be prorated, per hour ..... $30.00 
(5)  Righting an overturned vehicle or winching, when recovery is more than 20 feet from edge of roadway or is in water or marsh, per hour ..... $35.00 
(Ord. No. 832, § 22, 2-19-1986; Ord. No. 837, § 4, 5-7-1986; Ord. No. 928, § 1, 11-20-1996; Ord. No. 1045, § 1, 9-21-2016) 
Sec. 13-596. - When suspension authorized. 
The chief may suspend the wreckers of any wrecker service from the rotation system upon any of the following grounds: 
(1)  Charging fees in excess of those approved by the commission. 
(2)  Failure of a wrecker to pass inspection. 
(3)  Any violation of the provisions of this article or other law. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 23, 2-19-1986) 
Sec. 13-597. - Mandatory suspension. 
A court conviction of violation of section 13-568 or section 13-593 shall result in mandatory suspension of the wrecker service for a period of one year. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 24, 2-19-1986) 
Sec. 13-598. - Notice of suspension. 
Any wrecker service suspended from the rotation list by the chief shall be notified in writing of the suspension to take effect within ten days after notice, the reasons therefor in writing, the witnesses relied upon by the chief, and that the wrecker service shall be granted a hearing upon request before the city manager within such ten-day period. 
(Ord. No. 832, § 25, 2-19-1986) 
Secs. 13-599, 13-600. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT ESTABLISHMENTS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 934, § 2, adopted July 15, 1998, repealed former art. XVI of this chapter in its entirety and added new provisions as art. XVI as herein set out. Former art. XVI, §§ 13-601—13-615, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 930, § 2, adopted July 24, 1997. 

Sec. 13-601. - Title. 
This article shall be known and cited as "the adult entertainment ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 934, § 2, 7-15-1998) 
Sec. 13-602. - Definitions 
[The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
Adult arcade means any place to which the public is permitted or invited wherein, for any form of consideration, coin-operated or slug-operated or electronically, electrically or mechanically operated still- or motion-picture machines, projectors or other image-producing devices are maintained to show images to five or fewer persons per machine at any one time, and where the images so displayed are distinguished or characterized by the depicting or describing of "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas". 
Adult bookstore, adult video store, or adult novelty shop means a commercial establishment that, as one of its principal business purposes, offers for sale or rental for any form of consideration any one or more of the following: 
(1)  Books, magazines, periodicals or other printed matter, or photographs, films, motion pictures, video cassettes or video reproductions which depict or describe specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas; or 
(2)  Instruments, devices or paraphernalia that are designed for use in connection with specified sexual activities. 
A commercial establishment shall be categorized as an "adult bookstore," "adult video store" or "adult novelty store" notwithstanding that it may have other principal business purposes if 50 percent or more of its floor space is utilized for the sale or rental of any of the foregoing items or if 50 percent of its inventory consists of the foregoing items. 
Adult cabaret or adult nightclub means a nightclub, bar, restaurant or similar commercial establishment, whether or not alcoholic beverages are served, that regularly features any of the following: 
(1)  Persons who appear nude or in a state of semi-nudity; 
(2)  Live performances that are characterized by the exposure of "specified anatomical areas" or by "specified sexual activities"; 
(3)  Films, motion pictures, video cassettes, slides or other photographic reproductions that are characterized by the depiction or description of "specified anatomical areas" or "specified sexual activities"; 
Adult entertainment means entertainment of the specific kinds included in the definitions herein of the several kinds of adult entertainment establishments, provided however, that the term "adult entertainment" shall not be construed to include, and this article shall not be construed to regulate, performances that are not distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on the depiction, description, display or featuring of "specified anatomical areas" or "specified sexual activities" in that such depiction, description, display or featuring of such areas or activities, if any, is only incidental to the primary purpose of the performance. 
Adult entertainment establishment means: (1) an adult arcade, an adult retail store, (3) adult cabaret or adult nightclub, (4) adult motel, (5) adult motion picture theater, (6) adult theater or (7) sexual encounter establishment as defined in this article. 
Adult motel means a motel, hotel or similar commercial establishment that offers accommodation to the public for any form of consideration and provides patrons with closed-circuit television transmissions, films, motion pictures, video cassettes, slides or other photographic reproductions that are characterized by the depiction or description of "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas" and advertises by any means the availability of such sexually oriented material. 
Adult motion picture theater means a commercial establishment where, for any form of consideration, films, motion pictures, video cassettes, slides or similar photographic reproductions are regularly shown that are characterized by the depiction or description of "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas". 
Adult theater means a theater, concert hail, auditorium or similar commercial establishment that, for any form of consideration, regularly features persons who appear in a state of nudity or live performances that are characterized by the exposure of "specified anatomical areas" or by "specified sexual activities". 
Minor , for the purposes of this article, means any person who has not attained the age of 18 years. 
Sexual encounter establishment means a business or commercial establishment, that as one of its primary business purposes, offers for any form of consideration, a place where two or more persons may congregate, associate, or consort for the purpose of "specified sexual activities" or the exposure of "specified anatomical areas" or activities when one or more of the persons is in a state of nudity or semi-nude. The definition of sexually oriented businesses shall not include an establishment where a medical practitioner, psychologist, psychiatrist, or similar professional person licensed by the state engages in medically approved and recognized sexual therapy. 
Specified anatomical areas means any of the following: 
(1)  Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals or pubic region, anus, cleft of the buttocks, or the female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola, or any portion of the areola; 
(2)  Human male genitalia in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
Specified sexual activities means and shall include any of the following: 
(1)  The fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttocks, anus or female breasts; 
(2)  Sex acts, normal or perverted, actual or simulated, including intercourse, oral copulation or sodomy; 
(3)  Masturbation, actual or simulated; 
(4)  The displaying of the male or female pubic hair, anus, vulva or genitalia; or 
(5)  Excretory functions as part of or in connection with any of the activities set forth in (1) through (4) above. 
(Ord. No. 934, § 2, 7-15-1998) 
Sec. 13-603. - General regulations. 
(a)  No person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity shall operate, attempt to operate or advertise an adult entertainment establishment as defined in this article without a valid adult entertainment license issued pursuant to this article. 
(b)  An adult entertainment establishment licensee shall maintain and retain for a period of three years a record of the names, addresses and ages of all persons employed by the establishment. 
(c)  No minor shall be permitted to enter into an adult entertainment establishment unless accompanied by a parent or guardian, and the participation or employment of minors as defined in this article in the business of an adult entertainment establishment is strictly prohibited. 
(d)  No more than one of the seven categories of adult entertainment establishments as defined in this article shall be permitted at any single business location. 
(e)  No employee of an adult entertainment establishment shall fondle or caress any patron, and no patron shall be allowed to fondle or caress any employee. 
(f)  All live performances at any adult entertainment establishment shall be presented on a stage or platform intended for that purpose which is raised at least two feet above the level of the floor. 
(g)  No live performances shall be presented closer than four feet to any patron, and performers shall not be allowed to commingle in the audience while performing. 
(h)  No adult entertainment establishment licensee shall allow or permit an employee or any other person on the premises to engage in obscene live conduct as defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-80. 
(i)  No dancers or performers at an adult entertainment establishment shall solicit or accept any pay or gratuity from a patron, and no patron shall directly pay or give any gratuity or provide for any pay or gratuity to any dancer or performer. 
(j)  All interior areas of an establishment, as well as all walkways, parking areas and approaches to such establishment, licensed hereunder shall be fully lighted at all times patrons are present. Full lighting shall mean illumination equal to 3.5 foot candles per square foot for the interior spaces and 1.5 foot candles per square foot for exterior areas. 
(k)  No adult entertainment establishment shall serve, sell, distribute or allow the consumption of any alcoholic beverages upon the premises of the licensee. This subsection shall not apply to any adult entertainment establishment which was in business and held a license to serve alcoholic beverages prior to July 25, 1997, provided, however, that this exclusion shall only apply to present operators of such establishments, and shall only apply so long as the nature of the adult entertainment at such establishments does not change (for example, a change from adult motel to adult cabaret, or a change from "topless" dancing to nude dancing at a cabaret, would nullify this exclusion). This exclusion as to subsection (k) shall not excuse such establishments from compliance with the remaining provisions of this article or from other alcoholic beverage license provision of the City Code of ordinances. 
(l)  An adult entertainment establishment shall conspicuously display the licenses required by this article. 
(m)  No adult entertainment establishment except an adult motel shall be open for business between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. or at anytime on Sundays or Christmas day. 
(n)  No booth, screen, partition or other obstruction shall be permitted within the interior of any adult entertainment business so as to prevent a clear, unobstructed view throughout the interior of the premises, except for separate offices, kitchens, rest rooms or areas not frequented by patrons. 
(o)  No premises for an adult entertainment business shall have any interior connections or doors which make any other place of business accessible to customers or patrons. 
(p)  The interior of an adult entertainment establishment shall be enclosed from public view so that the activity therein is not visible from the exterior. 
(Ord. No. 934, § 2, 7-15-1998) 
Sec. 13-604. - Sales to minors. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, barter or give or to offer to sell, barter or give to any minor as defined in this article any services, material, device or thing sold or offered for sale by an adult entertainment establishment as defined herein which clearly depicts any "specified anatomical area" or promotes, instructs, or assists in the conduct of any "specified sexual activities". 
(Ord. No. 934, § 2, 7-15-1998) 
Sec. 13-605. - Location. 
(a)  Adult entertainment establishments shall not be permitted in any zoning districts within the city except districts zoned for general commercial and industrial uses. 
(b)  No adult entertainment establishment shall be located within 500 feet of any parcel of land upon which any establishment selling alcoholic beverages is located or upon which another establishment regulated or defined hereunder is located. 
(c)  No adult entertainment establishment shall be located within 500 feet of any parcel of land zoned for residential use. 
(d)  No adult entertainment establishment shall be located within 500 feet of any parcel of land upon which a church, cemetery, shrine, chapel of a mortuary, or other place used exclusively for religious services or meditation is located. 
(e)  No adult entertainment establishment shall be located within 500 feet of any school or any regular stop or shelter where a bus used for the transportation of school students boards or discharges minors. 
(f)  No adult, entertainment establishment shall be located within 500 feet of any parcel of land upon which a licensed day care center, hospital or nursing home is located. 
(g)  No adult entertainment establishment shall be located within 500 feet of any parcel of land upon which a public park or playground is located. 
(h)  No adult entertainment establishment shall be located within 500 feet of any parcel of land upon which a governmental building, library, or civic center is located, except where such building is located within the boundaries of a district zoned for general commercial or industrial uses. 
(i)  Where applicable distances specified herein shall be measured by airline from property line to property line. 
(j)  This section regarding location shall not apply to existing adult entertainment establishments in business prior to the effective date of this revised article.
