(2)  The application for a permit shall be submitted to the issuing authority and must include the applicant's erosion and sedimentation control plan with supporting data, as necessary. Said plans shall include, as a minimum, the data specified in subsection 17-5(c). Soil erosion and sedimentation control plans shall conform to the provisions of subsection 17-4(b). Application for a permit will not be accepted unless accompanied by two copies of the applicant's soil erosion and sedimentation control plans. 
(3)  A fee, in an amount of $150.00 shall be charged for each acre of the project area or fraction thereof. 
(4)  Immediately upon receipt of an application and plan for a permit, the issuing authority shall refer the application and plan to the district for its review and approval or disapproval concerning the adequacy of the erosion and sedimentation control plan. The results of the district review shall be forwarded to the issuing authority. No permit will be issued unless the plan has been approved by the district, and any variances required by subsections 17-4(b)(16) and (17) and bonding, if required as per subsection 17-5(b)(5), have been obtained. Such review will not be required if the issuing authority and the district have entered into an agreement which allows the issuing authority to conduct such review and approval of the plan without referring the application and plan to the district. 
(5)  a.  If a permit applicant has had two or more violations of previous permits, this section, or the Erosion and Sedimentation Act, as amended, within three years prior to the date of the filing of the application under consideration, the issuing authority may deny the permit application. 
b.  The issuing authority may require the permit applicant to post a bond in the form of government security, cash, irrevocable letter of credit, or any combination thereof up to, but not exceeding, $3,000.00 per acre or fraction thereof of the proposed land-disturbing activity, prior to issuing the permit. If the applicant does not comply with this chapter or with the conditions of the permit after issuance, the issuing authority may call the bond or any part thereof to be forfeited and may use the proceeds to hire contractor to stabilize the site of the land-disturbing activity and bring it into compliance. These provisions shall not apply unless there is in effect an ordinance or statute specifically providing for hearing and judicial review of any determination or order of the issuing authority with respect to alleged permit violations. 
(c)  Plan requirements. 
(1)  Plans must be prepared to meet the minimum requirements as contained in subsection 17-4(b) of this chapter. Conformance with the minimum requirements may be attained through the use of designed criteria in the current issue of the Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia, published by the state soil and water conservation commission as a guide, or through the use of alternate design criteria which conform to sound conservation and engineering practices. The Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia is hereby incorporated by reference into this chapter. The plan for the land-disturbing activity shall consider the interrelationship of the soil types, geological and hydrological characteristics, topography, watershed, vegetation, proposed permanent structures including roadways, constructed waterways, sediment control and stormwater management facilities, local ordinances and state laws. 
(2)  Data required for site plan: 
a.  Narrative or notes, and other information: Notes or narrative to be located on the site plan in general notes or in erosion and sediment control notes; 
b.  Description of existing land use at the project site and description of proposed project; 
c.  Name, address, and phone number of the property owner; 
d.  Name and phone number of 24-hour local contact who is responsible for erosion and sediment controls; 
e.  Size of project or phase under construction, in acres; 
f.  Activity schedule showing the anticipated starting and completion dates for the project. Include the statement in bold letters that: "The installation of erosion and sedimentation control measures and practices shall occur prior to or concurrent with land-disturbing activities"; 
g.  Stormwater and sedimentation management systems-storage capacity, hydrologic study and calculations, including off-site drainage areas; 
h.  Vegetative plan for all temporary and permanent vegetative practices, including species, planting dates and seeding, fertilizer, lime, and mulching rates. The vegetative plan should show options for year-round seeding; 
i.  Detail drawings for all structural practices. Specifications may follow guidelines set forth in the Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia; 
j.  Maintenance statement - "Erosion and sedimentation control measures will be maintained at all times. Additional erosion and sedimentation control measures will be installed if deemed necessary by onsite inspection." 
(3)  Maps, drawings and supportive computations shall bear the signature/seal of a registered or certified professional in engineering, architecture, landscape architecture, land surveying or erosion and sedimentation control. The certified plans shall contain: 
a.  Graphic scale and north point or arrow indicating magnetic north; 
b.  Vicinity maps showing location of project and existing streets; 
c.  Boundary line survey; 
d.  Delineation of disturbed areas within project boundary; 
e.  Existing and planned contours, with contour lines drawn with an interval in accordance with the following: 

 
f.  Adjacent areas and features areas such as streams, lakes, residential areas, etc., which might be affected should be indicated on the plan; 
g.  Proposed structures or additions to existing structures and paved areas; 
h.  Delineate the 25-foot buffer adjacent to state waters and the 35-foot buffer in MRPA areas; 
i.  Delineate the 100-foot horizontal buffer along designated trout streams, where applicable; 
j.  Location of erosion and sedimentation control measures and practices, using coding symbols from the Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia, chapter 6. 
(4)  Maintenance of all soil erosion and sedimentation control practices, whether temporary or permanent, shall be at all times the responsibility of the property owner. 
(d)  Permits. 
(1)  Permits shall be issued or denied as soon as practicable but in any event not later than 45 days after receipt by the issuing authority of a completed application, providing variances and bonding are obtained, where necessary. 
(2)  No permit shall be issued by the issuing authority unless the erosion and sedimentation control plan has been approved by the district and the issuing authority has affirmatively determined that the plan is in compliance with this chapter, any variances required by subsections 17-4(b)(16) and (17) are obtained, bonding requirements, if necessary, as per section 17-5, are met and all ordinances and rules and regulations in effect within the jurisdictional boundaries of the issuing authority are met. If the permit is denied, the reason for denial shall be furnished to the applicant. 
(3)  If the tract is to be developed in phases, then a separate permit shall be required for each phase. 
(4)  The permit may be suspended, revoked, or modified by the issuing authority, as to all or any portion of the land affected by the plan, upon finding that the holder or his successor in title is not in compliance with the approved erosion and sedimentation control plan or that the holder or his successor in title is in violation of this chapter. A holder of a permit shall notify any successor in title to him as to all or any portion of the land affected by the approved plan of the conditions contained in the permit. 
(5)  No permit shall be issued unless the applicant provides a statement by the finance director certifying that all ad valorem taxes levied against the property and due and owing have been paid. 
(Ord. No. 927, § 2, 8-21-96) 
Sec. 17-6. - Inspection and enforcement. 
(a)  The building official will periodically inspect the sites of land-disturbing activities for which permits have been issued to determine if the activities are being conducted in accordance with the plan and if the measures required in the plan are effective in controlling erosion and sedimentation. If, through inspection, it is deemed that a person engaged in land-disturbing activities as defined herein has failed to comply with the approved plan, with permit conditions, or with the provisions of this chapter, a written notice to comply shall be served upon that person. The notice shall set forth the measures necessary to achieve compliance and shall state the time within which such measures must be completed. If the person engaged in the land-disturbing activity fails to comply within the time specified, he shall be deemed in violation of this chapter. 
(b)  The building official shall have the power to conduct such investigations as he may reasonably deem necessary to carry out duties as prescribed in this chapter, and for this purpose to enter at reasonable times upon any property, public or private, for the purpose of investigation and inspecting the sites of land-disturbing activities. 
(c)  No person shall refuse entry or access to any authorized representative or agent of the issuing authority, the conservation commission, the district or division who requests entry for the purposes of inspection, and who presents appropriate credentials, nor shall any person obstruct, hamper or interfere with any such representative while in the process of carrying out his official duties. 
(Ord. No. 927, § 2, 8-21-1996) 
Sec. 17-7. - Penalties and incentives. 
(a)  Failure to obtain a permit for land-disturbing activity. If a person commences any land-disturbing activity requiring a land-disturbing permit as prescribed in this chapter without first obtaining the permit, the person shall be subject to revocation of his business license, work permit or other authorization for the conduct of a business and associated work activities within the jurisdictional boundaries of the issuing authority. 
(b)  Stop work orders. Upon notice from the issuing authority, work on any project that is being done contrary to the provisions of this chapter or in a dangerous or unsafe manner shall be immediately stopped. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property, his authorized agent or the person or persons in charge of the activity on the property, and shall state the conditions under which work may be resumed. Where an emergency exists, no written notice shall be required. 
(c)  Bond forfeiture. If, through inspection, it is determined that a person engaged in land-disturbing activities has failed to comply with the approved plan, a written notice to comply shall be served upon that person. The notice shall set forth the measures necessary to achieve compliance with the plan and shall state the time within which such measures must be completed. If the person engaged in the land-disturbing activity fails to comply within the time specified, he shall be deemed in violation of this chapter and, in addition to other penalties, shall be deemed to have forfeited his performance bond, if required to post one under the provisions of subsection 17-5(b)(5). The issuing authority may call the bond or any part thereof to be forfeited and may use the proceeds to hire a contractor to stabilize the site of the land-disturbing activity and bring it into compliance. 
(d)  Monetary penalties. Any person violating any provision of this chapter, permitting conditions, or stop-work order shall be liable for a monetary penalty not to exceed $2,500.00 per day, by a sentence of imprisonment not exceeding 60 days in jail or both fine and jail or work alternative. Each day during which the violation or failure or refusal to comply continues shall constitute a separate violation. 
(e)  EPD enforcement action. Upon written request made by this issuing authority, the director may determine that the public interest requires the initiation of an enforcement action by the division. Such request shall be accompanied by documentation that demonstrates to the director's satisfaction that local remedy has been exhausted and that compliance with local ordinances or resolutions has not been achieved. Where such a determination is made and this issuing authority has failed to secure compliance, the director may implement the board's rules and seek compliance under provision of O.C.G.A. § 12-7-12 through § 12-7-15. For the purposes of this subsection, enforcement actions taken by the division pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-7-12 through § 12-7-15 shall not require prior revocation of certification of this issuing authority. 
(Ord. No. 927, § 2, 8-21-1996) 
Sec. 17-8. - Administrative appeal; judicial review; and liability. 
(a)  Administrative remedies. The suspension, revocation, modification or grant with condition of a permit by the issuing authority upon finding that the holder is not in compliance with the approved erosion and sediment control plan; or that the holder is in violation of permit conditions; or that the holder is in violation of any ordinance; shall entitle the person submitting the plan or holding the permit to a hearing before the city manager within ten days after receipt by the issuing authority of written notice of appeal. 
(b)  Judicial review. Any person aggrieved by a decision or order of the issuing authority, after exhausting his administrative remedies, shall have the right to appeal de novo to the superior court of the county. 
(c)  Liability. 
(1)  Neither the approval of a plan under the provisions of this chapter, nor the compliance with provisions of this chapter shall relieve any person from responsibility for damage to any person or property otherwise imposed by law nor impose any liability upon the issuing authority or district for damage to any person or property. 
(2)  The fact that a land-disturbing activity for which a permit has been issued results in injury to the property of another shall neither constitute proof of nor create a presumption of a violation of the standards provided for in this chapter or the terms of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 927, § 2, 8-21-1996) 
Chapter 18 - SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1010, § 1, adopted Feb. 18, 2009, deleted Ch. 18 and enacted a new Ch. 18 to read as set out herein. Former Ch. 18 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 650, §§ 1—9, adopted June 6, 1973; Ord. No. 686, § 1, adopted Aug. 6, 1975; Ord. No. 854, § 2, adopted Sept. 2, 1987; and Ord. No. 857, § 1, adopted Sept. 16, 1987. 
Cross reference— Sidewalks to be kept clean, § 19-12; utilities, ch. 22. 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to provide garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. 1983, art. IX, § 2, ¶ III(a)(2); Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; litter control, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-40. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this chapter the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
Brown goods means electrical consumer goods such as, but not limited to, televisions, computers, and audio equipment that are mainly used for home entertainment. 
Collector means a person who under formal agreements, verbal or written, with or without remuneration, does the work of collecting and hauling solid wastes. 
Curbside means the placing of garbage in a proper container as hereinafter set forth at the edge of the street or adjacent alley for collection on prescribed days. 
Disposal area means a site, location, tract of land or facility used or intended to be used for the final disposal of solid wastes, garbage, putrescible waste, hazardous waste or other waste, except that it shall not include the land or facility used for the disposal of solid waste or other waste from a single-family dwelling on which the owner, occupant or lessee of such land or facility resides. 
Dwelling unit means a building or portion of a building designed, occupied, or intended for occupancy as separate living quarters, with cooking, sleeping, and sanitary facilities provided therein. The term dwelling unit shall not be deemed to include individual rooms or suites in a hotel, motel, rooming house or hospital. 
Federal Poverty Guidelines means the Federal Poverty Guidelines for the year in which an exception is sought as issued from time to time by the United States Department of Health and Human Services. 
Garbage means food waste, including waste accumulation of animal or vegetable matter used for or intended for food or that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruits or vegetables. 
Hazardous waste means material in a solid or semi-solid state resulting from the manufacture or use of pesticides or drugs (other than normal household use), pathological wastes, chemical wastes, flammable or explosive materials, and similar waste material in a solid or semi-solid state, which the city manager may consider a likely hazard to the public health or safety, except radioactive waste materials, as provided in rules of the state department of natural resources. 
Industrial waste or industrial solid waste means the solid waste materials from factories, processing plants and manufacturing enterprises, and includes food processing wastes, meat and poultry processing waste, hatchery waste, construction and demolition waste, condemned food, ashes and cinders from power plants, agriculture products waste, land clearance waste and similar wastes. 
Junk means items which are too large for 95-gallon containers and typically consist of, but is not limited to, household items such as lawn equipment, furniture, mattresses and box springs, large pieces of glass and mirrors, automotive parts, flooring materials and other similar items. 
Mobile home park means an undivided parcel of land under single management which is used or intended to be used for rental or lease of spaces or lots and the provision of services for two or more mobile homes. 
Premises means land, buildings or other structures, vehicles, watercraft or parts thereof, upon or in which solid waste is stored. 
Private solid waste collector means a person, not under the employ of the City of Brunswick, who under formal agreements, verbal or written, with or without remuneration, does the work of collecting and hauling solid wastes. 
Roll-off container means a bulk solid waste receptacle placed temporarily in the yard or driveway of a lot used to handle solid waste disposal related to temporary activities such as, but not limited to, moving, remodeling, or other construction at a site. The container is hauled away when it is full and is emptied by mechanical means. Hazardous waste is not allowed to be placed in roll-off containers. Hazardous waste is not allowed in roll-off containers. 
Rubbish means a variety of combustible and noncombustible waste materials not subject to rapid decomposition derived from places of residence, commercial areas and institutions which shall include paper, rags, plastics, cartons, boxes, tree and yard trimmings, furniture, appliances, metals, minerals, cans, bottles, glass, crockery, excelsior, beddings, rubber, discarded clothing and similar materials. 
Scavenge means uncontrolled picking from discarded solid waste materials. 
Solid waste means putrescible and nonputrescible waste, except human body waste, and shall include garbage, rubbish, paper, cartons, boxes, wood, tree branches, yard trimmings, furniture, appliances, metals, tin cans, glass, crockery, dunnage, ashes, street refuse, dead animals, waste materials generated in industrial operations, residue incineration, food processing wastes, demolition wastes, construction wastes and any other wastes in a solid or semisolid state not otherwise defined in this section. 
Waste means unwanted or discarded material, except human body waste. 
(Ord. No. 1044, § 1, 11-4-2015) 
Sec. 18-2. - Penalties for violations. 
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter and is convicted therefore shall be punished in accordance with section 1-6 of this Code. Certain conduct described in this section shall be deemed a violation of this Code and violations of this Code shall be subject to minimum fines as follows: 
(a)  Any person who dumps or places or discards any trash, garbage or other solid waste on property not owned by that person shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter and shall be punished by a fine of not less than $500.00, along with any other and additional penalties imposed by the court. 
(b)  Any person who dumps or places or discards any trash, garbage or other solid waste in or upon any city street, right-of-way, sidewalk, ditch, park, square or other property of the city shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter and shall be punished by a fine of not less than $500.00, along with any other and additional penalties imposed by the court. 
(c)  Any person who dumps or places or discards any motor vehicle tire or any refrigerator, air conditioner, freezer, stove, dishwasher, clothes washer or dryer, ice maker, television, computer visual monitor, or other appliance on property not owned by that person, including any property owned by the city shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter and shall be punished by a fine of not less than $750.00 along with any other and additional penalties imposed by the court. 
(d)  Each occurrence of dumping as described above in this section shall be deemed a separate violation and shall be punished as such. 
(e)  Every violation occurring subsequent to the first conviction under this section shall be punished by a fine not less than $1,000.00, along with such other and additional penalties as may be imposed by the court. 
(f)  It is intended that the foregoing shall constitute minimum penalties and the court is encouraged to impose such additional penalties and remedies as are within the jurisdiction of the court; the minimum penalties set forth herein are not the exclusive penalties applicable to such violations. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009; Ord. No. 1013, § 1, 10-21-2009) 
Sec. 18-3. - Responsibility for administration. 
The city commission, in order to protect the health and safety of the people of the city authorizes and directs its city manager, by implementing and enforcing the provisions of this chapter, to control the storage, collection and disposal of solid waste in the incorporated areas of the city. He or she shall plan, organize, procure equipment and personnel, and manage a publicly-owned and operated solid waste collection and disposal service and/or establish criteria for evaluation of private collection and disposal services, make recommendations to the commission regarding contracts for solid waste collection and/or disposal between the commission and private collectors and/or disposal site owners and/or operators, and shall regulate the establishment, maintenance and operation of public or private solid waste collection and/or disposal systems, methods and sites. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-4. - Functions of city manager. 
Collection, transportation and disposal of solid waste shall be under the supervision and control of the city manager. He or she shall have authority to establish routes and days of collection, types and locations of solid waste containers, and such other matters pertaining to collection, transportation and disposal of solid waste as he may find necessary and to change and modify the same after notice as required by law, provided such measures are not contrary to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-5. - Industrial solid waste. 
The rules and regulations contained in this chapter shall not prohibit the producers of industrial waste or the owner of premises upon which industrial solid waste has accumulated from collecting, transporting and disposing of such waste, subject to laws and regulations pertinent thereto, if such service is not provided by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-6. - Appeals. 
Any person aggrieved by a requirement of, or fee charged by, the city manager shall have the right of appeal to the city commission which may confirm, modify or revoke any such requirement of fee. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-7. - Control of private disposal sites. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or permit to be deposited on land under his ownership and control any solid waste without having first obtained a disposal area permit as required by regulations of the state department of natural resources and the acceptance of the site by the city manager for such use and purpose. 
(b)  The city manager or the authorized representative of the state department of natural resources shall be permitted to enter private disposal sites at any time during normal business hours for free and unhindered inspections to determine compliance with this chapter and all other pertinent laws and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-8. - Charges. 
(a)  Solid waste service charges for the purpose of financing collection and disposal systems and for acquisition of disposal sites shall be as enacted by the city commission from time to time. 
(b)  Fees and charges imposed by this section shall become an obligation of each unit of residence and each unit of commercial establishment, unless otherwise specified in this chapter. 
(c)  The City of Brunswick may impose a fee schedule for fees and charges related to solid waste collection by resolution from time to time as it sees fit. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-9. - Collection of fees by the City of Brunswick for fees for service prior to January 1, 2010. 
Prior to January 1, 2010, the City of Brunswick may collect for charges and bills for solid waste service via a monthly bill to the owner of the commercial establishment, owner of the residence, renter or lessor of a commercial establishment, renter or lessor of a residential establishment, or owner or lessor of any other establishment located within the City of Brunswick. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-10. - Collection of fees by tax commissioner or city commission designee for fees for service on and after January 1, 2010. 
Beginning on January 1, 2010 and continuing thereafter, all billing for solid waste service in the City of Brunswick shall be billed under the following procedure. Bills for the subsequent year may be issued and become due prior to the date of service. Therefore, bills for the year 2010 may be billed in the year 2009, but shall be bills for service for the year 2010. The following procedure shall be followed beginning with billing for service to be received in the year 2010: 
(a)  All fees for solid waste collection and disposal may be assessed upon the tax commissioner's books for each year and may be collected by the tax commissioner, should the city commission choose to designate the tax commissioner as the point of collection for fees for solid waste. After collection, the tax commissioner or whoever the city commission may designate shall transfer the solid waste fee to the city treasury at the same time as city ad valorem taxes. In collection, of this solid waste fee, the tax commissioner or city commission designee shall have the authority to resort to any remedy or right allowed by law for the collection and payment of city ad valorem taxes. 
(b)  The tax commissioner or city commission designee shall prepare and mail to each owner of residential property and to each owner of a non-homestead mobile home an annual billing for solid waste fees. The property owner shall be assessed a solid waste fee for each dwelling unit on the property. The solid waste fee will appear as a separate line item assessment on the owner's annual property tax bill and shall become due and payable at the same that city taxes are due and payable. Each year's payment entitles the property owner to solid waste collection and disposal service for each dwelling unit at that property location for the succeeding year. If the solid waste fees remain unpaid, the tax commissioner or an authorized designee, shall have the authority to issue a writ of fieri facias or execution against the property served. The writ of fieri facias or execution shall have the same lien dignity and priority as a writ of fieri facias or execution issued for city ad valorem taxes. Each annual installment shall become a lien against the property served on January 1 of each year in the same manner and the same priority that lien attaches for city ad valorem taxes. Any solid waste fee that remains unpaid shall accrue penalty, interest, and fieri facias charges in the same manner and the same rate as delinquent city ad valorem taxes. 
(c)  There shall be no free service offered by the City of Brunswick for solid waste sanitation service except as otherwise provided in this chapter. 
(d)  The city commission of the City of Brunswick may choose to provide exceptions to the collection of solid waste service via the tax commissioner or whoever the city commission may designate, by instead submitting billing through other means which are hereby enumerated: 
(1)  Mobile home parks and multi-family dwellings: 
a.  Mobile home parks and rental dwellings whose sanitation is serviced by the City of Brunswick, or its designee: In lieu of payment of this solid waste fee, an owner of a mobile home park or two or more rental dwellings may produce proof to the City of Brunswick Finance Manager clearly showing undivided management of each rental dwelling or of the mobile home park and its intended use for rental or lease space or lots for two or more mobile homes. The owner of the mobile home park or the rental dwellings will be billed quarterly at the rate of ¼ of the annual fee and will pay quarterly in advance for the sum total of all the mobile homes located on the parcel, regardless of habitation, or the sum total of rental dwellings within the city boundaries regardless of habitation. 
b.  Mobile home parks and rental dwellings whose sanitation is not serviced by the City of Brunswick, or its designee: In lieu of payment of the solid waste fee in its entirety, an owner of a mobile home park or a rental dwelling may produce proof to the City of Brunswick Finance Manager, clearly showing payment of the full year fees to a private vendor or an executed contract with a private vendor to provide for on-site solid waste collection services for all dwelling units on the property for the entire service year. If the contract between the property owner and the private vendor should be terminated at any time during the service year, the property owner shall give written notice to the city finance manager within three business days of termination of the contract. Property owner shall have seven business days from mailing such notice to obtain replacement solid waste collection and disposal service from a private vendor and produce proof of this service to the city finance manager. Notice shall be deemed given on the date of mailing the notice. If the property owner does not obtain replacement service and produce proof of that service to the city finance manager within seven business days of the notice of termination, the city finance department shall bill in full the solid waste fee to the property owner on a pro-rated basis with the owner paying 1/12 of the annual fee for each of the months or parts of months remaining in that year for all billable units located on the property. 
(2)  Commercial establishments: In lieu of payment of this solid waste fee via the tax commissioner or whoever the city commission may designate, an owner of a commercial establishment may produce proof to the city manager, or his or her designee, showing payment of a full year's fees to a city licensed private solid waste collector or an executed contract with a private solid waste collector to provide for on-site solid waste collection services for the owner's commercial establishment for the entire service year. If a commercial establishment does not provide proof of payment or a contract with a private solid waste collector the City of Brunswick shall, in lieu of payment of the solid waste fee via the tax commissioner or whoever the city commission may designate, bill for solid waste service via a bill for monthly service to the registered address of the owner of the commercial establishment. 
(3)  Tax exempt properties: In lieu of payment of this solid waste fee via the tax commissioner or whoever the city commission may designate, all tax-exempt properties, which are exempt via the United States Internal Revenue Code, § 501(c), shall be billed for solid waste service via a monthly bill to the registered address of the tax exempt property and/or organization. 
(4)  Low income: Any occupied or unoccupied dwelling unit, owned in whole or in part by an individual whose income falls below the federal poverty guidelines for the service year may be excepted from an annual payment of the solid waste fee and billed on a monthly basis by the City of Brunswick Finance Department. In order to qualify for the exception, the individual must submit an application in accordance with subsection (e) of this Code each year, including individuals who have previously applied for and received this exception. 
(5)  Disability: Any occupied or unoccupied dwelling unit owned in whole or in part by an individual who, as of January 1 of the service year, has been found, adjudicated, or declared totally (100 percent) disabled and unable to work by either the U.S. Social Security Administration or U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs and whose income falls below the federal poverty guidelines, may be excepted from an annual payment of the solid waste fee and billed on a monthly basis by the City of Brunswick Finance Department. 
(6)  Unoccupied property: Any unoccupied dwelling unit owned in whole or in part by an individual who is 62 years old or disabled as defined above as of January 1 of the service year and whose income falls below the federal poverty guidelines may be exempt from any annual or regular payment of the solid waste fee. 
(7)  Other exceptions: The city manager may make recommendations to the board of commissioners at any time to consider amendments to provide for further exceptions. 
(e)  Application for exception: Applications for exceptions may be obtained from the City of Brunswick customer service counter on the first floor of city hall. The City of Brunswick Finance Manager or his or her designee must receive all applications and required documentation for exceptions for the service year in question by August 1 of the service year at 5:00 p.m.; no applications will be accepted after that date. 
(f)  Approval or denial of application for exception: The city finance manager, in her sole discretion, shall approve or deny the application for exception. All decisions will be made within five business days of submission of the application. 
(g)  Appeals: A person aggrieved by the city finance manager's discretion may apply to the city manager within 30 days of the decision of the finance manager. The decision of the city manager shall be final. No appeal shall be considered if it is received by the city manager after the 30-day period has run. All decisions regarding appeals will be made within ten business days of submission to the city manager. 
(h)  Partial year service: If construction is begun on undeveloped residential property after January 1 of the service year, the City of Brunswick Finance Department shall bill the property owner upon the issuance of a certificate of occupancy for the property. The solid waste fee in such instance shall be assessed on a prorated basis with the owner paying 1/12 of the annual fee for each of the months or parts of months remaining in that year. This fee will be due in full and payable at the time of issuance of the certificate of occupancy. 
(i)  Uninhabitable property: Property designated by the City of Brunswick Building Inspector to be uninhabitable in accordance with the City of Brunswick Housing Code, may be excepted from the solid waste removal fee for the period of time the property is bound by such classification. Upon the removal of the uninhabitable classification, the owner of the property shall be assessed a pro rata solid waste removal fee for the remainder of that service year. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009; Ord. No. 1036, § 1, 4-16-2014) 
Sec. 18-11. - Air pollution controls. 
(a)  No person shall set fire to, or burn, any papers or other solid waste deposited at the disposal site or on the ground thereof. 
(b)  No garbage or other materials from which offensive or noisome odors emanate during combustion shall be burned outside of any building. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-12. - Acceptable solid waste. 
The following classes of solid waste shall be acceptable for disposal at publicly owned and operated disposal sites: 
(1)  Garbage. 
(2)  Ashes, the residue from burning of combustible materials for fuel. 
(3)  Rubbish. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-13. - Unacceptable solid waste. 
The following classes of solid waste shall not be acceptable for disposal at public expense on publicly owned and operated disposal sites: Industrial waste, solid or semisolid waste resulting from industrial processes in excessive quantities, as determined by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-14. - Hazardous waste and dead animals. 
When suitable personnel, area, equipment and time are available, hazardous waste and large dead animals over 100 pounds in weight may be accepted at the disposal site for final disposal in a separate and specifically prepared disposal area if necessary, at the discretion of the city manager who shall assess and collect for the city fees for such disposal. Interference with and delay of routine disposal operations shall be avoided by prior arrangement and scheduling of delivery to the disposal site by the owner of the hazardous waste or dead animals. Fees for hazardous waste disposal shall be based upon actual cost of disposal plus 25 percent of cost to cover records, land use, equipment maintenance, and administration. Fees for animal disposal shall be set from time to time by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-15. - Authorized sites. 
Sites approved for final disposal of solid wastes shall be designated by appropriate signs posted near the roadside. Such sites shall be maintained in use until permanently closed in accordance with pertinent laws and regulations. At that time additional authorized sites shall be opened and publicized by posting and through the press. All solid waste shall be delivered and deposited at authorized disposal sites in accord with the directions and orders of the city manager or his representative in charge of operation except privately operated sites may be used for sanitary disposal of industrial waste or other specified waste upon approval of the city manager and upon receipt of a disposal area permit issued pursuant to regulations of the state department of natural resources. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-16. - Operating hours. 
Authorized disposal sites shall be operated Monday through Saturday of each week, with the exception of holidays, from 8:00 a.m., to 6:00 p.m., inclusive. During such hours acceptable solid waste generated in the city, except industrial waste, shall be received for disposal from any person. Except for bona fide residents of the city disposing of garbage or refuse from his residence, a charge for landfill use will be made, as established from time to time by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-17. - Responsibility of users. 
(a)  Persons entering into contracts with the commission for collection of solid wastes shall sign and file with the city manager a general release which shall absolve the city, its officers and employees, from responsibility for any accident to such contractors or their employees or for damage to trucks or other property owned or operated by such contractors or employees when such accident or damage occurs at a city-operated disposal site or on the grounds thereof. 
(b)  No person shall enter a disposal site except when an attendant is present and during the hours and days prescribed in section 18-14, unless a specific agreement to do so has been executed by the city manager. All materials delivered and deposited for disposal on the grounds of disposal sites shall be the property of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-18. - Salvage. 
No person shall be permitted to salvage, scavenge or reclaim any solid waste which has been delivered to a public disposal site for disposal except a person who has executed a contract for salvage rights with the city, in accordance with the rules and regulations of the state department of natural resources. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Secs. 18-19—18-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION PROCEDURES 

Sec. 18-36. - Collection by city. 
All solid waste generated or accumulated in the incorporated areas of the city shall be collected, transported and disposed of by the city through its designated agents, employees or contract representatives. No other person shall collect, transport, or dispose of any solid waste generated or accumulated in the city except as provided. 
(1)  Private solid waste contractors, operating within areas approved by the city manager, must comply with this chapter and all applicable city ordinances, including licensing and franchising ordinances. 
(2)  Individual residents may transport their own solid waste to approved disposal sites, provided they comply with all applicable city, state, and federal ordinances and laws. Any individual resident who chooses to transport their own solid waste to an approved disposal site will remain liable for any pertinent solid waste fees. 
(3)  For backdoor waste collection services for disabled residents or elderly residents with medical hardships, there will be no additional charge with proof of disability or hardship from a licensed medical professional or other proof as deemed by the city manager or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-37. - Containers. 
(a)  Solid waste containers shall be provided by the owner or occupant of each residence, industry, place of business, congregation or institution. For individual residential properties the solid waste container shall be a 95-gallon container unless otherwise designated by the city manager or his or her designee or otherwise specified in this chapter. For all other structures and properties in the City of Brunswick such solid waste containers shall be either a 95-gallon container, a six-cubic yard container, an eight-cubic yard container, or another container as designated by the city manager or his or her designee unless otherwise specified in this chapter. 
(b)  All putrescible waste (including pet and animal body waste, but not including leaves and yard trimmings and not including rags, paper, cans, cartons and boxes which contain no putrescible matter) shall be placed for collection in sturdy, durable, rust-resistant, nonabsorbent, watertight containers which provide protection against intrusion or scattering of such waste by animals. Any waste containing pet or animal body waste shall be separately wrapped in unbroken, securely sealed containers prior to being placed in garbage containers. Disposable bags may be used for storage and collection of such putrescible waste and pet and animal body waste provided that disposable bags containing such waste must be placed for collection inside a sturdy solid waste container as otherwise required by this subsection. 
(c)  Non-putrescible waste, leaves and yard trimmings, and rags, paper, cans, cartons and boxes which contain no putrescible matter may be placed in disposable bags for collection, provided that such bags must be tied, must not be overfilled or overweighed, and must otherwise be used in a manner to avoid spillage and scattering. 
(d)  Containers for putrescible waste shall be equipped with handles and tight-fitting covers and shall have a capacity of not more than 32 gallons, provided that business, commercial and other establishments or entities which generate solid waste in quantities exceeding five cubic yards per week shall provide commercial containers of a design approved by the city manager. Such containers shall be suitable for dumping by all of the city's mechanized commercial collection equipment. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place any garbage, trash or refuse for collection in any receptacle not meeting the requirements of this section. No wooden boxes, pails or barrels shall be used for garbage or refuse, and the collectors shall be required to remove all such boxes or barrels. 
(f)  In the event that any person shall have a receptacle for garbage or trash which shall not conform to the requirements of this chapter or shall become unacceptable by reason of use or other cause, the city manager or his or her designee shall place or cause to have placed a tag thereon notifying the owner thereof of such fact. In the event such receptacle is not replaced or repaired to conform to the requirements of this section prior to the next regularly scheduled pickup, the city manager shall have the authority to refuse to pick up garbage from such unacceptable receptacle, or to have the nonconforming container removed by the collectors. 
(g)  Any solid waste containers which are obtained on or after March 1, 2009, by any person within the city from the City of Brunswick shall be subject to a deposit fee. Such deposit fee shall apply to every solid waste container obtained on or after March 1, 2009, and shall be a deposit fee to be set by resolution of the city commission, from time to time. All solid waste containers which are obtained before March 1, 2009 shall be grandfathered in and shall not be liable for any deposit fee to the City of Brunswick. However, if a city resident shall choose to obtain an additional solid waste container or obtain a new solid waste container on or after March 1, 2009, then that container shall be subject to the aforementioned deposit fee. 
(h)  In the event that all fees for solid waste collection and disposal are not paid in a timely manner the City of Brunswick shall remove any and all solid waste containers of the delinquent customer until such time as all fees for solid waste collection and disposal are paid. Any solid waste container which has been collected by the City of Brunswick because fees for solid waste collection and disposal were not paid in a timely manner shall be subject to the provisions of subsection (g), above, regardless of whether the container is re-obtained by the customer before or after March 1, 2009. Therefore, any customer who has become delinquent in his payment of fees for solid wasted collection and disposal to the City of Brunswick and has had his solid waste container removed by the city, must pay all fees for solid waste collection and disposal owned to the City of Brunswick and a deposit fee to be set by resolution of the city commission, from time to time, to have such container returned. 
(i)  All delinquent customers shall continue to be charged for solid waste collection and disposal even after any and all solid waste containers have been removed by the City of Brunswick and shall be fully liable for any and all charges accrued whilst delinquent and whilst containers are not present. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-38. - Preparation. 
(a)  Garbage and rubbish shall be drained of excess liquid before being placed for collection. 
(b)  Rubbish, when placed in containers or bundles, must not be over 50 pounds gross weight when placed for collection. Limbs or cuttings shall not be over four feet in length and four inches in diameter, and shall be stacked separately, with the butt ends in the same direction. Leaves, straw and similar items must be placed for collection in neat piles, separate from all other rubbish, immediately behind the curb on curbed streets, and immediately adjacent to the roadway on uncurbed streets. In no event will they be placed in the gutter or drainage ditches. 
(c)  Larger items in size or weight shall be handled at special fees which may be established based upon size of crew, size and weight of the items, and time of service, with minimum charges set by resolution of the city commission. Further details for collection of such larger items is described below in section 18-46. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to trim trees for compensation within the city unless the trimmings and limbs and trash resulting there from are immediately removed from the premises and placed or deposited by the contractor in a disposal site. 
(e)  Building materials, such as stone, dirt, plaster, lumber, brick, roofing, concrete, etc., or other materials from contract labors, shall not be collected or removed by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-39. - Storage. 
(a)  No person shall place any solid waste in any street, public place, roadway, or on private premises except in proper containers for collection or under the express prior approval of the city manager. No person shall place any solid waste in any stream, lake or other body of water. 
(b)  Any unauthorized accumulation of solid waste on any premises is hereby declared to be a violation hereof and is prohibited. Failure to remove any existing accumulation of solid waste within such reasonable time as may be fixed by written notice of the city manager shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. 
(c)  Solid waste to be collected by the city or its representative shall be placed on the curb or roadway in front of the residence or establishment in which it has been accumulated, but not in the street, drainage ditches or in the gutter. 
(d)  Residential garbage containers shall not be placed further from the street than five feet beyond the rearmost projection of the residence building, except where pickup is made from the rear of the lot. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-40. - Scavenging. 
No person other than the owner thereof, or an agent or employee of the city manager, or any employee of a person holding a contract with the city for collection of solid waste shall interfere with any container placed for the purpose of storing solid waste pending collection, or remove or take any of the contents thereof, or remove any such container from the location where same shall have been placed by the owner thereof, unless permission to do so has been granted by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-41. - Collection limitations. 
No person shall contract for the collection, transportation, or disposal of solid waste who does not possess a current license for such business operation in the city. Applications for licenses shall be written and shall be considered after evidence has been presented to show that the applicant has received a current permit, appropriate to the type of business concerned, as required under the solid waste regulations of the state department of natural resources. Licenses shall then be issued in accordance with criteria established by the city manager after payment therefore has been made in full as set forth in section 18-8. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-42. - Private solid waste collectors. 
(a)  No private solid waste collector shall be allowed to engage in the business of collecting, transporting, or disposing of solid waste within the city limits of the City of Brunswick without first obtaining a license from the city. 
(b)  Private solid waste collectors must contract with the city commission to engage in the business of collecting, transporting or disposing of solid waste within the city limits of the City of Brunswick. Such private solid waste collectors must have obtained an appropriate solid waste permit in accordance with regulations of the state department of natural resources. Persons contracting for solid waste collection shall, before engaging in such business, be licensed by the city and shall conform to all regulations providing for safe and sanitary collection and transportation of waste to a point of disposal, and shall execute a bond to the city in the sum of not less than $100,000.00 with a responsible surety company duly authorized to do business in the state, to be approved by the commission who shall establish conditions for the full and faithful performance of all agreements and covenants in such contract. 
(c)  Any private solid waste collector who does not obtain a license from the City of Brunswick to engage in the business of collecting, transporting, or disposing of solid waste within the city limits of the City of Brunswick within 90 days of receiving written notice of the requirement to do so, shall be cited for each violation. For this section, every individual collection, transportation, and disposal shall count as a violation and a private solid waste contractor may be cited for each individual violation. 
(d)  A license granted pursuant to this chapter to any private solid waste collector shall be subject to the police power of the city to adopt and enforce general ordinances necessary to the safety and welfare of the public; and the private solid waste collector shall be required to comply with all applicable general laws and ordinances enacted by the city pursuant to such power. 
(e)  Licenses granted pursuant to this section of this chapter of the City Code of Brunswick shall be limited in scope as to allow the licensee to engage in the business of collecting, transporting, and disposing of solid waste within the city limits of the City of Brunswick, but not preventing other licensees from conducting business within the city limits and not preventing the city itself from conducting business within the city limits. 
(f)  Before a private solid waste contractor license shall be granted or renewed, the applicant shall pay a license fee in accordance with a fee scale or percentage scale which shall be established by the city commission by resolution from time to time. All private solid waste contactors operating in the City of Brunswick will be required to provide annual financial reports to the City of Brunswick indicating gross sales within the city limits of the City of Brunswick. 
(g)  Private solid waste contractors, operating within the city, may only operate in relation to commercial establishments within the City of Brunswick. 
(h)  Vehicles to be used on streets and highways for solid waste collection, transportation or disposal shall be kept clean and shall be certified in regard to highway safety by the motor vehicle division of the state department of public safety. Such vehicle bodies shall be in good condition and repair, covered and constructed in such manner that the contents thereof cannot be spilled, leaked or blown from the vehicle. The outside of the body shall be painted and identified by the name, telephone number and permit number of the person owning the collection business in letters and numbers not less than three inches high and easily legible. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-43. - Dead animal collection. 
Small dead animals, not over 100 pounds in weight, if kept separate from garbage and rubbish, will be collected without charge upon notice to the city manager or his or her designee, provided that a charge will be made for all such animals collected from animal hospitals, kennels, pet shops and the like. Owners of large dead animals shall be responsible for their removal and disposal. The city manager may remove large dead animals upon request, and charge an appropriate fee there for. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-44. - Residential collection. 
The phrase "residential collection," for the purposes of this section, means placing of cans and/or suitable containers at curbside as hereinbefore set forth on the days of collection. Cans placed on the public right-of-way shall be placed for collection by 8:00 a.m., and shall be removed on the day of collection not later than 12:00 midnight. Bins and other fixed structures are prohibited on the public way. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-45. - Roll-off containers. 
The use of roll-off containers in the city is prohibited unless such roll-off container is obtained through the City of Brunswick Public Works Department, other department of the City of Brunswick as the city manager may designate, or other entity as the city manager may designate. Any roll-off container which is obtained for use in the city without the permission of the appropriate department or entity shall be in violation of this section and the person, persons, or business responsible for obtaining that roll-off container shall be found in violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-46. - White goods, brown goods, and junk. 
As described in section 18-38, larger items in size or weight shall be handled at special fees which may be established based upon size of crew, size and weight of the items, and time of service, with minimum charges set by resolution. These fees shall be determined by the City of Brunswick Public Works Department and such minimum fee for such collection may be set by the city commission from time to time by resolution. Larger items may be, but are not limited to, items classified in the below groups. All hazardous waste must be properly and legally removed from white goods, brown goods, and junk prior to the city collecting such items. 
(a)  White goods. 
(1)  Stoves. 
(2)  Ovens. 
(3)  Refrigerators. 
(4)  Dishwashers. 
(5)  Washer/dryer. 
(6)  Hot water heaters. 
(7)  Microwaves. 
(8)  Gas and oil heaters. 
(9)  Other similar items and appliances. 
(b)  Brown goods and junk. 
(1)  Furniture. 
(2)  Mattresses and box springs. 
(3)  Windows and mirrors (must be taped and wrapped to prevent shattering). 
(4)  Lawn equipment (with all gas and oil properly drained). 
(5)  Automobile tires. 
(6)  Carpet/flooring. 
(7)  Plumbing/electrical materials. 
(8)  Car parts. 
(9)  Large electronic goods (televisions, computers, etc.). 
(10)  Other similar items. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-47. - Overflow trash. 
The city will pick up excess solid waste placed next to any city provided container, such as, but not limited to a 95-gallon container, a six cubic yard container, or an eight cubic yard container, as long as such excess solid waste is placed in a bag which has been approved by the City of Brunswick Public Works Department Director or his or her designee and as long as the current fees for any and all containers for that specific and particular property have been paid and there are no past due fees. The City of Brunswick Public Works Director or his or her designee shall issue in writing which type or types of bags are appropriate for city residents to place excess solid waste next to their city container. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 2-18-2009) 
Chapter 19 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Department of public works, § 2-216 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 5; housing, ch. 12; zoning, ch. 23; subdivision regulations, app. B. 
State Law reference— Municipal authority over streets and sidewalks, Ga. Const. 1983, art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4), O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3; municipal street systems generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-1. - Bills, posters, circulars, etc.—Distributing. 
All bills, posters, circulars or advertising matter, when distributed in the city, shall be delivered at the doors of residences personally to an inmate of such residences and not in any case left loose to be blown about the premises or streets. 
(Code 1953, § 3.2) 
Sec. 19-2. - Same—Posting. 
No person shall stick or post any handbill or placard of any description upon any public or private building or upon any post, fence, billboard, or any other structure or thing which is the property of another, without permission of the occupant or owner of such property. 
(Code 1953, § 3.3) 
Sec. 19-3. - Width of sidewalks, roadways, etc.—Generally. 
The widths of sidewalks, roadways, street parks and center-of-street grass plats, on all the streets and classes of streets in the city shall be as follows: 
(1)  On each 90-foot street in the business section the width of the sidewalk on each side of the street shall be 12 feet and the width of the roadway shall be 66 feet. 
(2)  On each 90-foot street in the residence section the width of each sidewalk shall be eight feet, and there shall be two roadways, the width of each of which shall be 25 feet. 
(3)  On each 80-foot street in the business section, each sidewalk shall be 12 feet in width, and the roadway shall be 56 feet wide. 
(4)  On each 80-foot street in the residence section, the width of each sidewalk shall be eight feet in width, and there shall be two roadways, each 20 feet wide. 
(5)  On each 60-foot street in the residence section, each sidewalk shall be six feet wide, there shall be two parks, each six feet wide, and one roadway 36 feet wide; except on Norwich Street, north of F Street on which portion of such street the sidewalks shall be eight feet wide and the two parks shall be four feet wide. 
(6)  On each 50-foot street in the business section, each sidewalk shall be ten feet wide and the one roadway shall be 30 feet wide. 
(7)  On each 50-foot street in the residence section, each sidewalk shall be five feet wide, there shall be two parks, each five feet wide and one roadway 30 feet wide. 
(8)  On each 45-foot street in the business section, each sidewalk shall be nine feet wide and there shall be one roadway 27 feet wide. 
(9)  On each 45-foot street in the residence section each sidewalk shall be six feet wide, there shall be two parks, each three feet wide and one roadway 27 feet wide. 
(Code 1953, § 33.1) 
Sec. 19-4. - Same—Future street improvements. 
All future street improvements in the city shall be planned and executed so that the same shall conform to and comply with the provisions of section 19-3. On any street where sidewalks or other street improvements may now be constructed or in process of construction, the city reserves the right and power to compel the property owners to adjust or extend such sidewalks or other improvements so as to make the same comply with the provisions and requirements of the preceding section. 
(Code 1953, § 33.2) 
Sec. 19-5. - Underground connections generally—Permit required for excavations. 
No person shall be permitted to make any excavation or hole in any street, lane, alley or sidewalk in the city for the purpose of laying gas pipes, water pipes, sewer or drain pipes or underground conduits, without first obtaining a written permit so to do signed by the city engineer or director of public works, or his authorized agent. 
(Code 1953, § 33.8) 
Sec. 19-6. - Same—Depth of pipes. 
All pipes laid under sidewalks on shelled, graveled or improved streets shall be laid at least 20 inches below the top of the street curb or to such depth as may be designated by the city engineer or director of public works, or his authorized agent, in any particular instance, in case no curb exists and on unimproved streets. 
(Code 1953, § 33.9) 
Sec. 19-7. - Same—Trenches not to be filled until work inspected. 
No trench made for the purpose of laying mains or service pipes shall be filled until the city engineer or director of public works shall have inspected and approved the same. 
(Code 1953, § 33.10) 
Sec. 19-8. - Same—Trenches not to be left in unsafe condition. 
It shall be unlawful for any gas or water company, or servant of such company, or any plumber, or any other person, after having opened a trench or hole in any street, alley, lane or square, to keep or leave the same in an unsafe condition. 
(Code 1953, § 33.11) 
Sec. 19-9. - Excavations for purpose of placing poles, planting trees, etc. 
(a)  No person shall be permitted to make any excavations or hole in any street, lane, alley or sidewalk in the city for the purpose of placing poles, planting trees or for any other purpose whatsoever without first having obtained a written permit to do so from the city engineer and director of public works or his authorized agent. 
(b)  All poles or trees placed in any street, lane, alley or sidewalk shall be placed at such points as shall be designated by stakes driven by the city engineer and director of public works or his authorized agent. 
(Code 1953, § 33.15) 
Sec. 19-10. - Temporary excavations or obstructions—Permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to make any temporary excavation or to place any temporary obstruction or any pile of sand, brick or other paving or building material in or upon any street, sidewalk, square, lane or alley of the city, without first obtaining written permission so to do from the city manager. 
(Code 1953, § 33.16) 
Sec. 19-11. - Same—To be lighted at night. 
Any person who shall make any temporary excavation or who shall place or who shall own or control any temporary excavations or temporary obstruction, pile of sand, brick or other building or paving material in or upon any street, sidewalk, square, lane or alley of the city, under the provisions of section 19-10, shall see to it that from darkness to daylight of each night there shall be displayed a red light on each side and on each end of such temporary excavation or temporary obstruction, pile of sand, brick or other paving or building material. Such person shall see to it that such light shall be of such brightness that the same can be easily seen a block away. 
(Code 1953, § 33.17) 
Sec. 19-12. - Sidewalks to be kept clean. 
It shall be the duty of every person owning or renting any building or lot lying upon any street in the city to keep the sidewalks in a clean condition. 
(Code 1953, § 33.19) 
Sec. 19-13. - Fences, steps, etc., encroaching on streets, sidewalks, etc.—Prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to allow or erect any fence, railing, platform or steps, portico or other structure beyond the lot line, or so as to encroach on any street, square, alley or sidewalk of the city, except as provided in chapter 5 of this Code. 
(Code 1953, § 33.20) 
Sec. 19-14. - Same—Removal within 24 hours after notice. 
Any person maintaining any encroachment under the provisions of section 19-13 shall remove the same within 24 hours after notice so to do by the marshal or other officer. 
(Code 1953, § 33.21) 
Sec. 19-15. - Same—Failure to remove after notice; removal by city; cost. 
Upon failure or refusal of the person maintaining any encroachment under the provisions of section 19-13 to remove the same in obedience to the notice provided for in section 19-14, the same shall be removed by the marshal, and the cost of removal shall be collected from the person so offending by execution as in other cases. 
(Code 1953, § 33.22) 
Sec. 19-16. - Obstructions prohibited—By erection of stands, lunch wagons, etc. 
No person shall erect, place or maintain in, upon or over any sidewalk, street, alley, or other public place in the city, any fruit stand, shoeshining stand, flower stand, vegetable stand, lunch wagon, table, box, bin or other arrangement or structure for the display or sale of goods, wares or merchandise, or for the pursuit of any occupation whatsoever. 
(Code 1953, § 33.26) 
Sec. 19-17. - Same—By storage of merchandise, etc. 
No person shall use any sidewalk, street, alley or public place for the storage of personal property, goods, wares or merchandise of any kind; nor shall any person place or cause to be placed in or upon any sidewalk, street, alley or public place any barrel, box, hogshead, crate, package or other obstruction of any kind, or permit the same to remain thereon longer than is necessary to convey such article to or from the premises abutting on such sidewalk. 
(Code 1953, § 33.27) 
Secs. 19-18—19-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADDRESSING SYSTEM[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 948, § 1, adopted Mar. 6, 2002, deleted former art. II of this chapter and added new provisions as art. II as herein set out. Former art. II, §§ 19-36—19-42, pertained to house numbering and derived from the 1953 Code, §§ 33.38—33.44. 

Sec. 19-36. - Title, scope, intent and administration. 
(a)  Title. This article shall be entitled the "City of Brunswick Addressing Code." 
(b)  Authority and scope This article is enacted pursuant to the provisions of the Georgia Emergency Telephone Number "911" Service Act of 1977, at Section 120 et seq. of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, as amended. All powers granted to the governing authority of the county by the statute are hereby incorporated by reference so as to be assumed, delegated and granted pursuant to this article. 
(c)  Intent. The purpose of this article is to enhance the easy and rapid location of properties by law enforcement, fire, rescue, and emergency medical service personnel in the incorporated area of the city. It is found and declared by the city commission that establishing a physical addressing process will ensure that the new addresses will provide the best address information for the enhanced 9-1-1 database which can be used by emergency service providers, as well as by mail delivery services, utilities, delivery services, and others, for the health, safety and welfare of the people of the city. 
(d)  Administration. The county GIS department is hereby authorized to and shall approve road names and assign numbers to all properties, and shall administer this article. The GIS department, fire department, and police department will coordinate the approval of road names. All requests shall be submitted to GIS. GIS will relay requests to the police and fire departments for approval. GIS will strive to provide address approval the same day unless a problem or concern exists. An example of a problem could consist of a road name request that already exists within the same ESN area. These problems or concerns will be submitted to the public safety committee for review and approval. Members of the public safety committee are the police chief, fire chief, heads of utilities and public works, or their designees. The public safety committee will make a determination within in five working days of receipt of the problem or concern from GIS. The decision of the public safety committee is final and binding on all parties. 
(Ord. No. 948, § 1, 3-6-2002) 
Sec. 19-37. - Definitions. 
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article, unless otherwise specifically stated. 
Addressing means the assigning of a numerical address and street name, which name shall be numerical, to each location within the incorporated area of the city and replaces any route and box numbers currently in place in the "911" database. 
ESN means emergency service number, a geographic overlay defining different emergency service areas. 
GIS means geographic information system, or its successor, presently a department of the county government, as established by the county board of commissioners. 
Person means owner of a house, dwelling unit, or place of business. 
Property means any lot on which a permanent structure or building has been erected or could be placed. 
Road means any highway, road, street, avenue, lane, private way or easement, or similar paved, gravel, or dirt passage way. 
(Ord. No. 948, § 1, 3-6-2002) 
Sec. 19-38. - Naming system. 
All roads that serve two or more properties shall be named. A road name approved by the GIS department for addressing purposes which has been assigned to a private road shall not constitute or imply acceptance of the road as a public way and shall include the letters "P.E." after the name. Each P.E. (private easement) must be named. The following criteria shall govern the naming system: 
(1)  No two roads shall be approved with the same name in the same ESN, except when the roads intersect perpendicularly to one another and the names are followed by different suffixes (e.g., Oak Road and Oak Lane). This exception shall only be granted if the road name does not currently exist elsewhere in the same ESN. 
(2)  No two roads shall be approved with similar sounding names (e.g., Beach Street and Peach Street) unless they exist in a different ESN. 
(3)  Existing duplicate road names will be changed unless roads are located in: 
a.  Different geographic areas, such as the mainland of unincorporated Glynn County, St. Simon Island, and Sea Island; or 
b.  Different emergency service number zones (ESN). 
(4)  Existing duplicate roads will be renamed in the following order: 
a.  Road impacting the larger number of residents shall maintain the existing name. 
b.  Length of time road name has been in use. 
(5)  The main entrance into a subdivision shall have the same name as the subdivision unless it constitutes a public safety issue. 
(6)  Each road shall have the same name throughout its entire length in the incorporated area of the city. When a state highway has numerous names, the highway number will be used as the E-911 road name. 
(7)  No two subdivisions, condominiums, apartment complexes, hotels/motels, or shopping centers within the same ESN will be approved with the same name. 
(8)  Shopping centers shall have a road name assigned to the general primary public access drive of the shopping center. The road shall have the same name as the shopping center as approved by the GIS department. 
(Ord. No. 948, § 1, 3-6-2002) 
Sec. 19-39. - Numbering system. 
Assignment of address numbers shall be based on linear feet. In residential areas, address numbers shall be assigned every 60 feet along both sides of a road where possible. In commercial areas, address numbers shall be assigned every ten feet along both sides of a road where possible. The following criteria shall govern the numbering system: 
(1)  Four-way and "T" type intersections shall be numbered in the same manner as residences. 
(2)  Numbers shall be assigned from the point of beginning of each road. For dead end roads, numbering shall originate at the intersection of the adjacent road and terminate at the dead end road. From the point of beginning, address numbers shall be assigned even numbers on the right side and odd numbers on the left side of the road. 
(3)  Numbering shall begin at the main entrance to subdivisions and trailer parks. All other roads shall be numbered from the southern beginning point and proceed in a northerly direction, or from the western beginning point and proceed in an easterly direction. From the point of beginning, address numbers shall be assigned even numbers on the right side and odd numbers on the left side of the road. If a "911" accurate addressing system is presently in place, then new address assignments or any changes shall follow the existing "911" addressing system. 
(4)  The number assigned to each building shall be that of the numbered interval falling closest to the primary entrance. If the primary entrance cannot be seen from the street, then the number shall be that of the interval falling closest to the driveway of the building. 
(5)  Every multi-residential building with separate entrances shall have a separate number. For example, duplexes will have two separate numbers; condominiums will each have a separate number. 
(6)  Businesses, apartments and multi-tenant (three or more dwelling units) buildings shall have an address assigned to the primary entrance of the building. Apartment or suite numbers shall be assigned in ascending order from south to north or west to east end of the building. 
(7)  Sequential addressing numbers shall be assigned on lots in approved subdivisions with restrictive covenants assuring only one dwelling structure per lot. 
(Ord. No. 948, § 1, 3-6-2002) 
Sec. 19-40. - Designation of numbers and duty to display. 
All persons, by the date set forth in section 19-42 herein, shall display and maintain in legible condition the assigned numbers in a conspicuous place, as follows: 
(1)  Number on the building or residence. Where the building or residence is within 40 feet from the edge of the road right-of-way, the assigned number shall be displayed on the front of the building or residence near the primary entrance visible from the street or parking lot providing general public access. The same requirement applies to buildings, dwelling units, and place of business within apartments, condominiums, and nonresidential developments located on private streets. 
(2)  Number at the street line. Where the building or residence is over 40 feet from the edge of the road right-of-way, regardless whether the road is a private or public way or easement, the assigned number shall be displayed on a post, fence, wall, mailbox, or on some structure at the property line next to the walk or access drive to the building or residence. 
(3)  Size and color of number. The standard number shall be not less than three inches in height for residential, or less than six inches in height for non-residential and multi-tenant buildings, and with a contrasting background. The numbers shall not be more than one inch apart or equal to the width of any number except the number "1". Numerals shall be maintained in a legible condition and shall be visible at night. 
(4)  Temporary numbers. Each person constructing a building of any kind shall, during such construction, erect or post a temporary number, designated by "0" by the GIS department unless a permanent number can be assigned. This number shall not be smaller than five inches wide and 12 inches high and shall be posted not further than ten feet from the front of the lot upon which construction is being done. The number shall remain posted until a permanent number is assigned, erected or posted. This subsection (4) shall not apply to building permits issued for ancillary buildings that are accessory to the main building such as a separate vehicular garage, pool house or storage building. A temporary number will be assigned only when a permanent number cannot be assigned. 
(Ord. No. 948, § 1, 3-6-2002) 
Sec. 19-41. - Construction, subdivisions, and business licenses. 
(a)  Construction. Whenever any residence or other building is constructed or renovated, it shall be the duty of the owner to obtain an address number or verify the accuracy of the existing address number through the GIS department. The owner shall obtain or verify, as applicable. 
(b)  Subdivisions. It shall be the duty of any person who intends to subdivide property to obtain approval from the GIS department for any proposed road name in the subdivision. The proposed name of the subdivision and proposed street names shall not duplicate or too closely approximate, phonetically, the name of any other subdivisions or streets in the same ESN, except as set forth herein. 
(c)  Business licenses. All applications for new or renewed business licenses issued by the city finance department will be reviewed by the GIS department for correctness and compliance with this addressing article.
